Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Keyes v. Weller
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Two oft-invoked common-law veil-piercing theories are (1) alter ego, which is triggered when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased, and (2) when the corporate form is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Statute limiting liability of corporate agents had no effect on common-law fraud claims against agents for their own tortious conduct.

Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, the instrumentality test or the identity test are conducted to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate; if either test is satisfied, the corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: A corporation should be treated as a separate legal entity unless the corporate veil is pierced and the corporation is shown to be the alter ego of a controlling individual.

Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, ownership of an interest in the corporation is an essential part of the element of unity of ownership and interest in applying alter ego doctrine; if an individual's ownership is not established, the corporation's obligations cannot be imposed on him or her.

Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Although typically "ownership of an interest" refers to the corporation's stockholders, a wife's community property interest in her husband's stock holdings is sufficient to satisfy the ownership requirements for applying alter ego doctrine under California law.

Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, requisite ownership of an interest in the corporation, for purposes of applying alter ego doctrine, may exist for individuals who were actors in the course of conduct constituting the abuse of the corporate privilege.

Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Alter ego applies, supporting piercing of corporate veil, when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brightstar LLC v. Jordan
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division I.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a fact finder must find three elements by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the entity is the alter ego of the individual; (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the entity and the individual over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and (3) disregarding the corporate form will achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Arbitration. Arbitrator did not exhibit partiality against defendants by rolling his eyes or shaking his head in response to a witness evading questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brightstar LLC v. Jordan
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division I.
Headnote: As an element of piercing the corporate veil, an alter ego relationship exists when an entity is a mere instrumentality for the transaction of an individual's own affairs and the unity of interest in ownership is such that the separate personalities of the entity and the individual no longer exist.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Arbitration. Arbitrator did not exhibit partiality against defendants by rolling his eyes or shaking his head in response to a witness evading questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Although corporations are generally to be treated as separate legal entities, the equitable remedy of piercing the corporate veil may be available to a plaintiff in circumstances where it appears that the corporation is acting as the alter ego of a controlling individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Evidence that LLC's single member occasionally used LLC's property for personal enjoyment did not support alter ego determination.

Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine is to do justice whenever it appears that the protections provided by the corporate form are being abused.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Evidence that LLC's single member occasionally used LLC's property for personal enjoyment did not support alter ego determination.

Title: In re Ward
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Valdosta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, alter ego theory allows court to pierce corporate veil if it is shown that corporate entity is alter ego or business conduit of its owner.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The federal common law concerning piercing of the corporate veil tends to give less deference to the corporate form than does the strict alter-ego doctrine of state law.

Title: Estate of Ewers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego" is a theory by which a corporation's owner may be held personally liable for the corporation's liabilities, also known as piercing the corporate veil, if the claimant can show the owner used the corporation as a mere tool or business conduit for illegitimate purposes.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Investors' claims against LLC owner's estate for fraud and unjust enrichment were not barred by applicable statutes of limitations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Rodriguez v. Old West Export, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: A corporation is a distinct legal entity separate from its officers, unless exceptional circumstances demonstrate that the corporation may be disregarded and considered merely the alter ego of the persons composing it; thus, in general, where there is an injury to the corporation, the cause of action should be brought by the corporation, or by the shareholders derivatively if the corporation fails to act, and only for separate individual damage does an individual cause of action lie.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE  Perishable Commodities. Exceptional circumstances existed that supported disregarding of corporate form so that sole officer had standing for PACA trust claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Mohawk Construction and Supply Company, Inc. v. Walsh/Consigli JV
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Limited liability company and company related to joint venture were not liable for breach of subcontract between joint venture and subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Mohawk Construction and Supply Company, Inc. v. Walsh/Consigli JV
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or another corporation constitutes an alter ego, as required to pierce the corporate veil, a reviewing court must look for overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form, such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent, and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Limited liability company and company related to joint venture were not liable for breach of subcontract between joint venture and subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a corporation is functioning as an alter ego or a mere instrumentality of an individual or another corporation, it may be appropriate to disregard the corporate form and pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to find bar's owner and former owner personally liable for alleged assault on patron.

Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Washington recognizes the "alter ego" theory of corporate liability which provides that where a private person so dominates and controls a corporation that such corporation is his alter ego, court is justified in piercing the veil of the corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: To determine whether a corporation is a private person's alter ego, Washington courts look at (1) whether the corporate form was used to violate or evade a duty, and (2) whether the corporate form must be disregarded to prevent loss to an innocent party.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, for the first element of the "alter ego" theory of corporate liability to be met, the court must find an abuse of the corporate form, which typically involves fraud, misrepresentation, or some form of manipulation of the corporation to the stockholder's benefit and creditor's detriment.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, for the second element of the "alter ego" theory of corporate liability to be met, the court must find that wrongful corporate activities actually harmed the party seeking relief so that disregard of the corporate form is necessary.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: For purposes of the theory of alter ego liability, doctrine that corporation is a legal entity, separate and apart from persons composing it, is legal theory introduced for purposes of convenience and to subserve ends of justice, but concept will not be extended to point beyond its reason and policy, and when invoked in support of end subversive of said policy will be disregarded by courts.

Title: Scarborough v. LaRocca
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: A member of a limited-liability company (LLC) or a corporation who practices fraud upon a third party or breaches any professional duty or commits any other negligent or wrongful act may be found liable for the debts, obligations, or liabilities of the LLC or corporation; in that instance, a court can pierce the corporate veil in order to reach the alter ego of the corporate member and hold the corporate member liable for the debts of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Allegations of solidary liability between LLC member and LLC barred dismissing, as prescribed, former employee's unpaid-wage claims against member.

Title: Plan B Holdings, LLC v. RSLLP
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and impose liability under an alter-ego theory, the plaintiff must demonstrate (1) that the entity on which it seeks to impose liability is the alter ego of the debtor, and (2) that the corporate fiction was used for an illegitimate purpose, that is, to perpetrate an actual fraud on the plaintiff for the defendant's direct personal benefit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could pierce the corporate veil to hold sole owner of LLCs personally liable for unpaid attorney's fees under an alter-ego theory.

Title: Hacker v. Fabe
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: Two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked; first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In Connecticut, courts recognize two theories under which the corporate veil may be pierced, namely, the instrumentality rule and the identity rule; under either rule, veil piercing is not lightly imposed.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.

Title: Commercial Club Building LLC v. Global Rescue LLC

Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: The two-prong test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil from Minn. Laborers Health & Welfare Fund v. Scanlan, 360 F.3d 925, first requires the court to ask if there was such unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct; second, the court must consider if adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations; the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil bears the burden of showing both prongs of the test have been satisfied.

Title: BMO Harris Bank N.A. v. Kuskie

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court must consider common characteristics broadly utilized by reviewing courts in deciding whether to find an individual to be an alter ego of a corporate entity and disregard corporate form, and must keep in mind that, in each case in which reviewing courts have disregarded the corporate form, evidence demonstrated an abuse of that form through ongoing fraudulent activities of a principal, or a pronounced and intimate commingling of identities of the corporation and its principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Title: In re Wolf

Title: Philip Morris USA, Inc. v. Rintoul
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, litigants must prove three factors by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.

Title: Giron v. Zeytuna, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Technically, alter-ego liability and successor liability are distinct, although the terms are often used interchangeably: "successor liability" comes into play when a plaintiff tries to impose the liabilities of a predecessor corporation on a successor corporation; "alter ego liability" is related to veil-piercing, a legal doctrine by which the corporate form of an entity is disregarded.

Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in order to pierce the corporate veil, a court must first examine the totality of the evidence surrounding the owner's use of an artificial entity and, in particular, the manner in which the entity was employed in the manner at issue; from this evidence, the trial court must determine whether the evidence establishes that the owner operated the entity as his or her alter ego, that is, as a sham or mere agent or instrumentality of his or her will.

Title: In re Patel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, alter ego claim is action to impose liability on corporation's principals or related entities where corporation was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate fraud upon them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Patel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, when appropriate, courts will pierce corporate veil upon finding by preponderance of evidence that (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such extent that corporation's existence, was in fact nonexistent and shareholders were in fact alter egos of corporation; (2) corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Under Florida law, limited liability company (LLC) owned by debtor's daughter, that acquired and operated hotel, was not debtor's nominee.

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The "alter ego theory" for piercing the corporate veil applies only where the individual or corporate owner controls the corporation to be pierced and the controlling owner is to be held liable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Once an individual, individuals, or an entity elect to establish a corporation to gain the benefits of that business form, such persons and entities are not free to blur the lines of the capacity in which they act as it may suit them, and the courts must take care to maintain the necessary distinctions; when an owner does otherwise, he effectively pierces the corporate veil by intermingling personal interests with the corporation's interests.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When corporation is functioning as alter ego or mere instrumentality of individual or another corporation, it may be appropriate to disregard corporate form and pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brown v. End Zone, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: One exception that allows court to pierce the corporate veil is the alter ego theory which applies where the individual or corporate owner controls the corporation to be pierced, and the controlling owner is to be held liable.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Strip club operator was not entitled to a new trial on or remittitur of $820,000 compensatory damages and $500,000 punitive damages awarded to dancer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brown v. End Zone, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The alter ego theory, which allows a court to pierce the corporate veil, requires proof that the party or parent corporation exercised domination and control over the corporation, and that injustice will result if corporate fiction is maintained despite unity of interests between the corporation and its principal.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Strip club operator was not entitled to a new trial on or remittitur of $820,000 compensatory damages and $500,000 punitive damages awarded to dancer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is not a power that is lightly exercised; it may be appropriate when the corporate entity is (1) undercapitalized, (2) formed or operated with a fraudulent purpose, or (3) operated as an instrumentality or alter ego of its shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To establish that an entity is the alter ego of its owners such that piercing the corporate veil might be appropriate, the dominant party must have complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy, and business practices so that at the time of the attacked transaction the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Rotor Blade, LLC v. Signature Utility Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, to justify piercing corporate veil to hold a corporate officer personally liable under an alter ego theory, a plaintiff must allege facts plausibly showing that: (1) the corporate officer maintains complete control and domination of corporation's finances, policy, and business practices; (2) officer misused that control; and (3) this misuse proximately caused harm or unjust loss complained of; the court also considers whether corporate funds and officer's personal funds are intermingled and whether corporate funds are used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Industrial Equipment. Patentee did not allege underlying act of direct infringement required to state claim for indirect infringement of patent for tree-trimming method.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Pursuant to the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Jenkins v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue

Headnote: Alter-ego doctrine is an exception to the general rule that courts should respect the corporate form.

Title: Jenkins v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue

Headnote: One does not need to be a shareholder in a corporation to treat it as an alter ego; one needs to use it as if it were one's own property without respecting its separate personality.

Headnote: In considering whether corporation is alter ego, Arizona courts look to see if there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners cease to exist.

Headnote: Circumstances where supplanting state corporate law with federal common law is or may be necessary, for purpose of determining whether corporation is alter ego of individual, are few and far between.

Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano

Headnote: The "alter ego theory," which is an equitable doctrine, is a basis for disregarding the corporate fiction, where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Cork v. CC-Palo Alto, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To invoke California's alter-ego doctrine, under which the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, a plaintiff must allege: (1) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist; and (2) that if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Retirement community residents alleged they had property interest in entrance fees, as required to state claim for financial elder abuse.

Title: United States v. Weathers

Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine in Washington, a corporate entity is disregarded when the corporation has been intentionally used to violate or evade a duty owed to another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United States v. Weathers
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Tacoma.
Headnote: Under Washington law, an alter ego is found where one person so dominates and controls a corporation that a court is justified in piercing the veil of corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Fraudulent Conveyances. Under Washington's Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA), partners fraudulently transferred properties to partnerships to avoid tax liability.

Title: EST Inc. v. Royal-Grow Prods., LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, effect of alter ego doctrine is not to expand individual liability for individual actions; it is to bypass corporate form in only rarest of circumstances, such as, for example, fraud, such that individual becomes responsible for corporate liabilities when corporation cannot or will not meet its financial obligations. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 17-7101(b).
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Registration. Use of trademark on product shipment and sale documents did not constitute use in commerce, as prerequisite for registration of mark.

Title: EST Inc. v. Royal-Grow Prods., LLC

Headnote: Under Kansas law, alter ego doctrine, which generally imposes liability on an individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his own business, can only impose liability that is derivative of corporate liability.

Title: EST Inc. v. Royal-Grow Prods., LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, alter ego doctrine, which generally imposes liability on an individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his own business, does not create a novel, equitable cause of action against a corporation's shareholder where the corporation itself cannot be held responsible.

Title: Gold Crest, LLC v. Project Light, LLC

Headnote: Under Ohio law, the "complete control over the corporation" prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil is a restatement of the alter-ego doctrine, which requires the plaintiff to show that the individual and the corporation are fundamentally indistinguishable.

Title: Soter Technologies, LLC v. IP Video Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability only exists where the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation, usually a parent corporation, and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: ripKurrent LLC v. Richard Ballard IRA LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Alter ego is not a separate cause of action for which relief may be granted, but rather serves as a theory to impose liability on an individual for the acts of a corporate entity, and therefore should be alleged in the body of the complaint, and not as a separate count.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Florida LLC sufficiently alleged that managing member of Georgia consulting service purposefully availed himself of Florida forum by committing intentional tort.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, the three elements of corporate veil-piercing are: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation, (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Trustee did not establish that closely-held corporate debtor was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Flores v. Westmont Engineering Company
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: On certain occasions, the equitable remedy of piercing the corporate veil allows courts to pierce the veil of limited liability where the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of another person or entity; however, courts are reluctant to pierce the corporate veil, and a party asserting the doctrine has the burden of making a substantial showing that the entities are not separate and distinct.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Genuine issues of material fact as to roles of employer, landlord, and holding company precluded summary judgment in action by injured employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Frayman v. Douglas Elliman Realty, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, Florida law requires that a plaintiff show: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholder was in fact the alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Tenant sufficiently alleged causal connection between damages and rental of luxury house in violation of city ordinance to survive motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law, plaintiff must demonstrate that: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, and (2) the circumstances are such that adherence to fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: E.S. v. Best Western International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine as recognized under Texas law, courts disregard the corporate entity when there exists such unity between the corporation and individual that the corporation ceases to be separate, and when holding only one corporation liable would promote injustice.

Title: Succession of Blackwell

Title: Mathes Brierre Architects v. Karlton/ISG Enterprises, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a plaintiff must plead facts showing the following in order to pierce a corporate veil: (i) the defendant shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation lacked an independent existence and the defendant was in fact an "alter ego" of the corporation, (ii) the defendant engaged in "improper conduct" in the formation or use of the corporation, and (iii) the improper formation or use of the corporate form injured the plaintiff.

Title: In re Schaefers

Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine is applied to avoid inequitable results, not to eliminate the consequences of corporate operations.

Title: Clear Connection Corporation v. Comcast Cable Communications Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ming-Hsiang Kao v. Holiday
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, when the separate personality of a corporation is abused it will be disregarded and the corporation looked at as a collection or association of individuals, so that the individuals will be liable for acts done in the name of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. CEO and president of travel tour company were alter egos of their closely-held corporation, and thus personally liable for unpaid wages.

Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, court must first examine the totality of the evidence surrounding the owner's use of corporate entity and, in particular, the manner in which the entity was employed in the matter at issue; from this evidence court must determine whether the evidence establishes that the owner operated the entity as his or her alter ego, that is, as a sham or mere agent or instrumentality of his or her will.

Title: City and County of San Francisco v. Purdue Pharma L.P.

Headnote: The alter-ego doctrine is not limited to intentional fraud, nor does it require bad faith; so long as there is a unity of interest and ownership, courts will ignore the corporate form and attribute wrongful or inequitable conduct to the organization controlling the corporation.

Headnote: Under South Carolina law, alter ego doctrine is merely a means of piercing the corporate veil.

Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, alter ego claim requires a showing of: (1) total domination and control of one entity by another, and (2) inequitable consequences caused thereby.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: In addition to showing a unity of ownership, the party seeking to impose alter ego liability must show an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the entity alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re All Terrain, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: In order to establish an alter ego claim, plaintiff must prove (1) a unity of interest and ownership to a degree that the separate personalities of the individual and the corporation no longer exist, and (2) that an inequitable result would follow if the acts are treated as acts of corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Proof of claim could not be allowed on single business enterprise theory of veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: JTF Aviation Holdings Inc v. CliftonLarsonAllen LLP
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or succeed in an alter ego claim requires more under Arizona law than proof of the existence of an ownership relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, while "single business enterprise" theory provides a method for disregarding the legal distinctions between separate corporate entities and imposing personal liability for the debts of one corporation on a separate, but affiliated company, it is a distinct doctrine from the more traditional alter-ego liability theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, alter ego doctrine allows courts to disregard corporate formalities to the extent that corporation ceases to be distinguishable from its shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions Inc
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: A court may hold the owner of a corporation responsible for the corporation's conduct when there is a unity of interest between the individual and the entity, and when insulating the owner from liability would lead to inequitable results.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Assistance. Home health care provider knowingly submitted false Medicaid reimbursement claims and also did so with reckless disregard for their falsity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Saks Management and Associates, LLC v. Sung General Contracting, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where those who own or control a corporation have brought about such a unity of interest and ownership as between themselves and the corporation, the unpaid corporate creditor may look to them for satisfaction of the corporation's debts.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Industry Regulation. Repair rule exemption to ban on unlicensed contractors from enforcing construction contracts did not allow contractor to enforce contract.

Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: If the corporation is a facade for the personal dealings of the shareholder and the operations of the corporation are carried on by the shareholder in disregard of the corporate entity, the shareholder may be individually liable for corporate debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: The separate entity concept of the corporation may be disregarded, and corporate veil pierced to impose liability on the shareholder, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate business purpose, and is used as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud on the creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Nobel v. Foxmoor Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded, and the corporation and the shareholder treated as the same entity, if the corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the State.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Chief executive officer's inducement of investment and non-repayment of promissory note was not subject to Unfair and Deceptive Trade Practices Act.

Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: California's alter ego doctrine acts as a procedural mechanism by which an individual can be held jointly liable for the wrongdoing of his or her corporate alter ego.

Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, an alter ego relationship requires (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and its owner no longer exist, and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Holly v. Alta Newport Hospital, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to establish an alter ego relationship between a corporation and its equitable owner, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities do not in reality exist.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Records. Alleged negligence that led to public disclosure of hospital patient's private health information did not occur in rendering of professional services.

Title: Apple Inc. v. Allan & Associates Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: The unity of interest prong of the alter ego doctrine under California law requires a showing that the alter ego was controlled to such a degree that it was a mere instrumentality of the principal; it envisions pervasive control, such as when the principal dictates every facet of the alter ego's business, from broad policy decisions to routine matters of day-to-day operation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Limitations. Discovery rule did not apply to toll limitations period for seller's contract claim against company overseeing electronics-waste recycling program.

Title: Jass v. CherryRoad Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law governing alter ego theory of liability, a "unity of interest" means their general corporate actions are guided or determined not by two separate consciousness, but one.

Title: Angell v. Santefort Family Holdings LLC

Title: Lyle v. Fulcrum Loan Holdings, LLC

Title: Zhang v. Chu
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: Courts may disregard the corporate entity when the corporation is merely the alter ego of its stockholders: called "piercing the corporate veil," this equitable doctrine gives creditors access to the stockholders' personal assets when the corporation's assets are so minimal that their small size would defeat a plaintiff's judgment against the corporation, thus creating an inequitable result.

Title: Alexander v. Community Hospital of Long Beach
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Under the "alter ego doctrine," a corporate identity may be disregarded, the corporate veil pierced, where an abuse of the corporate privilege justifies holding the owner of a corporation liable for the actions of the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Substantial evidence did not support hospital's liability to nurses for negligent supervision of director alleged to have created hostile work environment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Alexander v. Community Hospital of Long Beach
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met to invoke the alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate identity: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist'; and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Substantial evidence did not support hospital's liability to nurses for negligent supervision of director alleged to have created hostile work environment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Johnson Trustee of Operating Engineers Local #49 Health and Welfare Fund v. Charps Welding & Fabricating, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: A corporation acts as another's alter ego if the corporation is (1) controlled by another to the extent it has independent existence in form only and (2) used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetuate a fraud.

Title: Constellation-F, LLC v. World Trading 23, Inc.

Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to invoke the alter ego doctrine must prove two conditions: (1) unity of interest and ownership between the two entities and (2) an inequitable result if the two entities are not equally liable.

Title: Eighteen Seventy L.P. v. Jayson

Title: Libersat v. Sundance Energy Inc.

Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: When a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego, the corporate form may be disregarded to achieve an equitable result.

Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, when a corporation operates as the mere instrumentality or alter ego of its sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of North Carolina, the corporate entity will be disregarded and the corporation and the shareholder treated as one and the same person.

Title: In re Bullitt Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: To veil pierce, Kentucky courts may proceed under a traditional alter ego formulation or an instrumentality theory, because the tests are essentially interchangeable; each resolves to two dispositive elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Church Joint Venture, L.P. v. Blasingame

Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must show that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that corporation was nonexistent and the shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation, (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to plaintiff.

Title: Sereda v. Center City Acquisitions, LLC

Title: AKH Company, Inc. v. Universal Underwriters Insurance Co.

Title: Durham v. Accardi

Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Unlike the instrumentality theory, under which there are three specific elements of proof, the identity theory is undifferentiated for purposes of determining whether piercing the corporate veil is proper.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re LXEng LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, Hartford Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, where the corporation functionally has no separate existence from the principal, the principal is the alter ego who controls and dominates the corporation's affairs.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Transfers by debtor limited liability company (LLC) to an insider fell within scope of fraudulent conveyance provisions of Connecticut statutes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Dao v. Faustin
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, piercing the corporate veil is justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and to adhere to that separateness would work an injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Permitting supervisor to return to work without facing disciplinary action was not adverse action for purposes of Title VII retaliation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Estate of Bogue v. Adams
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, a court must first inquire into whether the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Estate of Bogue v. Adams
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, an alter ego relationship exists when a corporation is a mere instrumentality for the transaction of the shareholders' own affairs, and there is such unity of interest in ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Estate of decedent adequately alleged timeliness of its Colorado-law breach of fiduciary duty claim against investment industry professionals.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Garza
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, McAllen Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego remedy applies when there is such an identity between a corporation and an individual that all separateness between the parties has ceased, and when a failure to disregard the corporate form would be unfair or unjust.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. No emotional distress damages could be awarded for secured creditor's stay violation in repossessing vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Life Technologies Corporation v. Govindaraj
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Reverse veil piercing attaches liability to the entity for a judgment against the individuals who hold an ownership interest in that entity; in contrast, "traditional" veil piercing permits a court to render an individual liable in a judgment against a business entity in which the individual has an interest, when the entity is in fact a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Judgment holding non-party president of corporation personally liable for damages awarded against corporation violated due process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts may pierce the corporate veil under one of two theories: either the instrumentality rule or the identity rule.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule for piercing the corporate veil requires the plaintiff to show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, in which case an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Title: In re Brugnara Properties VI
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: "Alter ego" is an entity lacking economic substance, essentially acting as the other self of an individual or entity.

Title: In re Brugnara Properties VI

Title: In re Brugnara Properties VI

Headnote: Veil-piercing under California law requires (1) such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of corporation and individual do not exist, and (2) that an inequitable result will follow if acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Taxing authorities could pierce veil separating taxpayers from wholly owned corporation.

Title: Sedgwick Properties Development Corporation v. Hinds
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division V.
Headnote: Inquiry into whether a corporate entity is the alter ego of the person or entity in issue looks to the specific facts of each case, and not all of the factors that a court may consider need to be shown in order to establish alter ego status.

Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Under the alter ego approach to piercing the corporate veil: there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment piercing the corporate veil contained insufficient findings to permit appellate review, and thus remand for further findings was required.

Title: In re Draw Another Circle.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, to state a claim for veil piercing, the plaintiff must plead facts supporting an inference that the corporation, through an alter ego, created an entity designed to defraud its investors and creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Piller v. Princeton Realty Associates LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: An alter ego will be established when either (1) there is complete domination of a corporation by an individual with respect to the transaction being attacked that resulted in a fraud or wrong against the complaining party, or (2) when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Arbitration award barred, under res judicata doctrine, LLC member's allegations that other member breached certain pre-arbitration promises.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, while veil-piercing and alter ego doctrines are interrelated and litigants often use the terms interchangeably, veil-piercing and alter ego doctrines can be distinguished in that veil-piercing asks a court to hold A vicariously liable for B's debts, while alter ego doctrine asserts that A and B are the same entity and therefore liability is direct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Title: Barenborg v. Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity

Headnote: The alter ego doctrine arises when a plaintiff comes into court claiming that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests; in certain circumstances the court will disregard the corporate entity and will hold the individual shareholders liable for the actions of the corporation.

Title: Dailey v. Ayers Land Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in order to hold the shareholder(s) actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable, there is normally a two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and of the individual shareholder(s) no longer exist, or a disregard of formalities requirement, and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, or a fairness requirement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. A genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether subdivision developer entered into a joint venture to create, develop, and market subdivision.

Title: In re Shapow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, San Fernando Valley Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under California law, plaintiff must prove: (1) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and of the individual no longer exist, and (2) that, if acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor failed to demonstrate any false oath in failing to schedules assets owned by debtor individually.

Title: Bates Energy Oil & Gas v. Complete Oilfield Services

Title: Eskelsen v. Theta Investment Company
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Both the "formalities requirement" and fairness requirement prongs of the Norman alter ego test must be met in order to make an alter ego claim and disregard a corporate entity and hold an individual liable as a debtor.

Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The test under Florida law to establish a claim for alter ego/piercing the corporate veil has three parts: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Trustee was not barred from asserting alter ego claim under Florida law, even though debtor was not a shareholder of any of the corporate defendants.

Title: Bazarian International Financial Associates, LLC v. Desarrollos Hotelco, C.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Courts apply the "alter ego" theory to cast aside the corporate shield and fasten liability on the individual shareholder when substantial ownership of corporate stock is concentrated in one person or a few persons, and other factors support disregarding the corporate entity in the interest of equity and fairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Under written agreement, investment banking company was entitled to recover unpaid debt fee, as damages, from developer and related entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Bazarian International Financial Associates, LLC v. Desarrollos Hotelco, C.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: There is neither a precise formula by which to predict when courts will pierce the corporate veil and assign liability upon individual shareholder, since each case is sui generis, nor a uniform standard to determine whether the evidence has sufficiently demonstrated unity of interest and ownership; the factor which predominates will vary in each case, influenced by considerations of who should bear the risk of loss and what degree of legitimacy exists for those claiming the limited liability protection of a corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Under written agreement, investment banking company was entitled to recover unpaid debt fee, as damages, from developer and related entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the fiction that corporations are distinct legal entities, separate from the individuals who comprise them, may be ignored when the corporation proves to be the alter ego of the shareholder; under this theory, a court may pierce the corporate veil in situations where fraud or deceit has been practiced by the shareholder acting through the corporation, or the corporation ceases to be distinguishable from its shareholders.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Title: Aaron Carlson Corporation v. Cohen
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil to hold a shareholder liable for the debts of the corporation when the shareholder is the alter ego of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor's veil-piercing claim was an improper collateral attack on receivership action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Atempa v. Pedrazzani
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Ordinarily, a corporation is regarded as a legal entity separate and distinct from its stockholders, officers and directors; under the alter ego doctrine, however, where a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Corporate employer's owner, president, secretary, and director was subject to civil penalties for employer's failure to pay appropriate wage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Atempa v. Pedrazzani
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: An application of the alter ego doctrine allows a court to disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the party actually controlling the corporation.

Title: Atempa v. Pedrazzani
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine is an equitable principle that elevates substance over form in order to prevent an inequitable result arising from unjustifiably observing a corporation's separate existence.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Corporate employer's owner, president, secretary, and director was subject to civil penalties for employer's failure to pay appropriate wage.

Title: Daimler AG v. A-Z Wheels LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: A party asserting the alter ego doctrine in California must show two requirements: (1) a unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone. Cal. Civ. Code § 3528.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Name or Likeness. Internet automobile wheel and rim sellers infringed on trademarks and patents.

Title: KDN Management, Inc. v. WinCo Foods, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Rexburg, May 2018 Term.
Headnote: Under Utah law, the first prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil, which requires such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, is often termed the "formalities requirement," referring to the corporate formalities required by statute; it is established upon a showing of the corporation's failure to observe said statutory formalities.

Title: Danos Tree Service, LLC v. Proride Trailers, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of piercing the corporate veil when shareholders fail to conduct the business on a corporate footing, such a failure can occur if the shareholder disregarded the corporate formalities to such an extent that the shareholder and the corporation became indistinguishable, or such unity existed that separate individualities ceased and the corporation was operated as the "alter ego" of the shareholder. La. Civ. Code Ann. art. 24.

Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and impose liability under an alter-ego theory, the plaintiff must demonstrate (1) that the entity on which it seeks to impose liability is the alter ego of the debtor, and (2) that the corporate fiction was used for an illegitimate purpose, that is, to perpetrate an actual fraud on the plaintiff for the defendant's direct personal benefit. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Title: Fuentes v. Zaragoza

Headnote: Corporate veil-piercing theories such as alter ego or single business enterprise cannot and do not abrogate the requirements of due process in the judicial system; parties must still be afforded notice and an opportunity to appear and defend themselves before being subjected to civil liability. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.

Title: Trisvan v. Heyman

Headnote: Alter ego liability exists under New York law when a parent or owner uses the corporate form to achieve fraud, or when the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation, usually a parent corporation, and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own.

Title: Richard Nugent and CAO, Inc. v. Estate of Ellickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: The concepts of alter ego and agency invoke different legal standards: an alter ego theory of liability, as typically applied in the corporate context, collapses the distinction between a corporation and its shareholder or shareholders by treating them as one and the same for liability purposes, whereas an agency relationship involves two distinct individuals or entities, with one (the agent) acting on behalf of the other (the principal).

Title: Turman v. Superior Court of Orange County
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met to invoke the alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate identity: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist; and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Trial court employed improper tests when determining alter ego and joint employer issues.

Title: Daewoo Electronics America Inc. v. Opta Corporation

Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor's alter ego and successor liability claims against affiliated companies of judgment debtor were not barred by res judicata.

Title: In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation
