Title: Curci Investments, LLC v. Baldwin
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked, on basis of a sham corporate entity having been formed for purpose of committing fraud or other misdeeds, two conditions generally must be met: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Judgment creditor was not per se precluded from reverse piercing corporate veil to add LLC, in which judgment debtor held interest, to judgment.

Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to determine whether there is a sufficient unity of interest to warrant piercing the corporate veil, courts consider various factors, including: (1) whether a single shareholder dominates the corporation, (2) whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, (3) whether the corporation has maintained minutes or adequate corporate records, (4) whether corporate funds and assets have been extensively intermingled with personal assets, and (5) fraudulent use of the corporation to protect personal business from the claims of creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Title: Fausse Riviere, L.L.C. v. Snyder
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Court may pierce the corporate veil under two exceptional circumstances: first, where the shareholders, acting through the corporation, commit fraud or deceit on a third party, the court will look to the shareholders for justice; secondly, the court may disregard the corporate identity where shareholders fail to conduct the business on a corporate footing, which failure can occur if the shareholder disregarded the corporate formalities to such an extent that the shareholder and the corporation became indistinguishable, or such unity existed that separate individualities ceased and the corporation was operated as the alter ego of the shareholder.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Land lessor was judicially estopped from asserting forfeiture and abandonment claim as to lessee's remaining property on the land.

Title: In re Rouette

Title: Lieberman v. Corporacion Experienca Unica, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The corporate veil is appropriately pierced through the alter ego theory under Pennsylvania law only where a corporation's affairs and personnel were manipulated to such an extent that it became nothing more than a sham used to disguise the alter ego's use of its assets for his own benefit in fraud of its creditors; in short, the evidence must show that the corporation's owners abused the legal separation of a corporation from its owners and used the corporation for illegitimate purposes.

Headnote: In determining whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership to warrant piercing corporate veil, courts may consider nature of corporate ownership and control, i.e., whether corporation is alter ego of individual who controls it; failure to maintain corporate records; failure to maintain corporate formalities necessary for issuance or subscription to stock; commingling of funds or assets; diversion of corporate funds or assets for personal use; and use of same office by corporation and by individuals.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator stated plausible false presentment and false statement claims against contractor's officers under False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: LSREF2 Clover Property 4, LLC v. Festival Retail Fund 1, LP
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: There are two standard requirements for finding alter ego and single business enterprise liability: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranty by borrower's limited partner was not a sham and thus antideficiency protections did not apply.

Title: LSREF2 Clover Property 4, LLC v. Festival Retail Fund 1, LP

Headnote: The alter ego doctrine generally applies when upholding the defendant's corporate form will work an injustice to an innocent plaintiff.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranty by borrower's limited partner was not a sham and thus antideficiency protections did not apply.

Title: LSREF2 Clover Property 4, LLC v. Festival Retail Fund 1, LP
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Alter ego is used to prevent a corporation from using its statutory separate corporate form as a shield from liability only where to recognize its corporate status would defeat the rights and equities of third parties; it is not a doctrine that allows the persons who actually control the corporation to disregard the corporate form.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Guaranty by borrower's limited partner was not a sham and thus antideficiency protections did not apply.

Title: TLIG Maintenance Services, Inc. v. Fialkowski

Title: Commonwealth Department of Environmental Protection v. Trainer Custom Chemical LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil through alter ego theory only where a corporation's affairs and personnel were manipulated to such an extent that it became nothing more than a sham used to disguise the alter ego's use of its assets for his own benefit in fraud of its creditors; evidence must show that the corporation's owners abused the legal separation of a corporation from its owners and used the corporation for illegitimate purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that LLC was undercapitalized and did not comply with corporate formalities was insufficient to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory.

Title: Chicago Regional Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. TMG Corporation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The alter ego analysis differs from the single employer doctrine, which determines whether two entities are a single employer, in that unlawful motive or intent is the most critical factor for finding alter ego status.

Title: In re Pocius

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, alter ego liability requires proof of the following two elements: (1) that a party exercised domination and control over corporate entity, and (2) that injustice will result if the corporate fiction is maintained despite a unity of interests between the entity and its principal.

Title: In re Carroll
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the conditions under which the corporate form may be disregarded vary according to the facts of each case, but generally, two requirements must be established for alter ego liability to exist: (1) there must be unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Jordan v. Maxfield & Oberton Holdings LLC

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the "unity of interest and ownership" prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil test is met, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Vernon

Title: In re Miller Parking Co., LLC

Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, before the alter ego doctrine can be invoked, two elements must be alleged: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Plaintiff can plead a number of different factors to show "unity of interest," and among factors to be considered in applying this prong of alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; this list is non-exclusive, and California courts have relied on host of other factors.

Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.

Headnote: A corporate entity will be disregarded where it would otherwise present an obstacle to the protection of private rights or where the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of the governing or dominant personality.

Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: To "pierce the corporate veil," a plaintiff must demonstrate that: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) the circumstances are such that adhering to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: In determining whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, as would support decision to pierce the corporate veil, a court generally will not rest its decision on a single factor, but will examine many factors, including: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether the corporation is a mere façade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Title: Green v. Ziegelman

Title: TradeWinds Airlines, Inc. v. Soros
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: TradeWinds Airlines, Inc. v. Soros
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, relevant considerations as to whether a corporation and its alleged alter ego acted as a single economic entity, as would support piercing the corporate veil, include: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors could not pierce veil to hold purported controllers of aircraft leasing corporation liable for default judgment.

Title: Deschepper v. Midwest Wine and Spirits, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) adhering to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Factors favored finding that, under FLSA, workers for liquor wholesaler were employees, rather than independent contractors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: SLAS Marine, Inc. v. Pounders
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine applies when individuals seek to use the corporate entity to avoid personal responsibility for debts or obligations of a corporation owned by them.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lease with purported owner who did not exercise physical acts of use, detention, or enjoyment over property was not valid or binding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida's veil-piercing law, corporate creditor may pursue claim against corporation's shareholder only where: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of corporation caused injury to the creditor seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Opus East, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, purpose of allowing corporate veil to be pierced on "alter ego" theory is to hold the party actually responsible for inequitable conduct accountable and to prevent that party from using another corporation to shield itself from liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Veil could not be pierced to augment estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Omega Demolition Corp. v. Hays Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, a court may pierce the corporate veil to hold a party liable for the acts of a corporate entity if the entity is used for a fraudulent purpose or if the party is the alter ego of the entity.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Parties. Client's action against insurance broker's parent could not proceed in equity and good conscience among existing parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Stanley v. Liberty
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Although law imposes more stringent standards for piercing the corporate veil in contractual disputes, the corporate veil can nonetheless be pierced when the evidence supports a finding that the corporation is merely an alter ego of an individual and when necessary in the interests of justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Arbitration. Closely held corporations and owner were not entitled to vacation of arbitration award in favor of former executive on breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Mihalatos
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Veil piercing and alter ego doctrines are logically and legally distinct under New York law; while veil piercing will always require proof of a wrong or fraud as well as injury, an alter ego finding, in and of itself, does not confirm the commission of a wrong or the occurrence of an injury, but merely recognizes what was a preexisting fact, that, at the time of the relevant transaction, the controlling principal and corporation were in actuality one and the same, the former inseparable from the latter.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Conduct regarding corporate assets did not necessarily bar individual Chapter 7 discharge.

Title: In re Mihalatos
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: By definition, an alter ego corporation possesses no independent identity or volition.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Conduct regarding corporate assets did not necessarily bar individual Chapter 7 discharge.

Title: Meridian North Investments LP v. Sondhi
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: It may be appropriate to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil if a corporation is functioning as an alter ego or mere instrumentality of an individual or another corporation.

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, "alter ego" is defined as a corporation used by an individual in conducting personal business, the result being that a court may impose liability on the individual by piercing the corporate veil when fraud has been perpetrated on someone dealing with the corporation.

Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma

Headnote: Under Mississippi law, to prevail on an alter-ego pierce-the-corporate-veil theory, a plaintiff must demonstrate fraud or misfeasance on the part of the shareholder that was perpetrated on someone dealing with the corporation.

Title: Ronaldo Designer Jewelry, Inc. v. Anne Ryan, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: While the general rule is that jurisdiction over an individual cannot be predicated upon jurisdiction over a corporation, courts have recognized an exception to this rule when the corporation is the alter ego of the individual.

Title: Ronaldo Designer Jewelry, Inc. v. Anne Ryan, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: Alter ego test for personal jurisdiction is less stringent than that for liability; the existence of either a shell corporation or fraud is sufficient by itself to justify jurisdiction.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Venue. Dismissal of copyright and trademark infringement action under doctrine of forum non conveniens was not warranted.

Title: Digby Adler Group LLC v. Image Rent a Car, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine arises when a plaintiff claims that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests, such that the court should disregard the corporate entity and hold the individual shareholders liable for the actions of the corporation.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Award of $25,000 in statutory damages was appropriate in van rental service's cybersquatting suit against two competing companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Digby Adler Group LLC v. Image Rent a Car, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, there are two general requirements for piercing the corporate veil: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Award of $25,000 in statutory damages was appropriate in van rental service's cybersquatting suit against two competing companies.

Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the "alter ego doctrine" arises when a plaintiff comes into court claiming that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, before the alter ego doctrine can be invoked, two elements must be alleged: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Author failed to allege that there was a contract between her and entertainment company that produced film allegedly based on her novel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The "alter-ego doctrine" is an exception to the general rule that, ordinarily, a corporation is regarded as a legal entity, separate and apart from its stockholders; if a party can prove its alter-ego theory, then that party may pierce the corporate veil and obtain a judgment against the individual shareholders even when the original cause of action arose from a dispute with the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The "Norman test" is a two-part test to determine when a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil and obtain judgment against individual shareholders; the first part of the test, often called the "formalities requirement", requires the movant to show such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and the second part of the test, often called the "fairness requirement", requires the movant to show that observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or condone an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: For one corporate entity to be the alter ego of another, as could support imposition of vicarious liability on the other, plaintiffs must show evidence of unity of control, that observance of alleged alter ego's corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, and that the individuality or separateness of the two has ceased to exist.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Statute providing that airport authority functions as agency of county did not impose vicarious liability on county.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ott v. Mortgage Investors Corp. of Ohio, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon, Portland Division.
Headnote: Under the fiduciary shield doctrine, a person's mere association with a corporation that causes injury in the forum state is not sufficient to permit that forum to assert jurisdiction over the person; however, the fiduciary shield may be disregarded in cases in which the corporation is the agent or alter ego of the individual defendant or when there is an identity of interests between the corporation and the individuals.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Recipients of telemarketing calls stated claim for violation of Telephone Consumer Protection Act.

Title: Baby Phat Holding Co., LLC v. Kellwood Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To state a claim for alter-ego liability, the plaintiff is generally required to allege complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Purchaser stated a breach of contract claim against seller's parent company, based upon an alter-ego theory.

Title: Gilman v. Walters
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Evansville Division.
Headnote: In order to establish that corporation is merely alter ego, two showings must be made: first, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and second, circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause indicated parties' intent to confer on arbitrator authority to determine his own jurisdiction.

Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, to justify disregarding a corporate entity, the plaintiff must show the principals disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs, and that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.

Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, piercing the corporate veil, or finding that a company is the alter ego of an individual, is justified where the owner treats the company and himself as one unit, or where the owner uses corporate funds for personal expenses.

Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, the alter ego and veil piercing doctrines are used as remedies for inequitable conduct which allow corporate creditors to pursue individual shareholders on corporate debts; the doctrines do not invalidate the corporate existence except for purposes of a particular creditor's debt collection.

Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: A primary purpose of doing business as a corporation is to insulate stockholders from unlimited liability for corporate activity; in certain circumstances, however, the corporate form may be disregarded, such as where the corporation stands as the alter ego or the business conduit of another, dominating personality.

Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.

Headnote: The alter ego doctrine fastens liability on the individual or entity that uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business.

Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.

Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil where: (1) a unity of interest and ownership appears so strong that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, and (2) under the circumstances, adhering to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances.

Title: Pencheng Si v. Laogai Research Foundation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.

Title: In re LLS America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Washington.
Headnote: Under Washington law, a court may pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego theory when the corporate entity has been disregarded by the principals themselves so that there is such a unity of ownership and interest that the separateness of the corporation has ceased to exist.

Title: Toumazou v. Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus

Title: Nutt v. Kees
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Arkansas, Jonesboro Division.
Headnote: A basis for piercing the corporate veil exists under the alter ego doctrine, if the corporation: (1) is controlled by another to the extent that it has independent existence in form only, and (2) is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate a fraud.

Title: In re McCauley

Headnote: Under Utah law, the alter ego doctrine permits courts to disregard the integrity of the corporation, view a controlling shareholder as indistinguishable from the corporation, and allow creditors of the corporation to reach assets of a controlling shareholder; this type of claim is often referred to as "piercing the corporate veil."

Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, the alter ego doctrine is intended to prevent the legal separation between the corporation and the controlling shareholder or shareholders from being used to perpetuate an injustice on third parties.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee failed to establish that limited liability company (LLC) belonged to debtor based on alter ego theory under Utah law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: To invoke the alter ego doctrine under Utah law, there must be a concurrence of two circumstances: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, viz., the corporation is, in fact, the alter ego of one or a few individuals; and (2) the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.

Title: Liberty Synergistics, Inc. v. Microflo Ltd.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Takiguchi v. MRI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: To hold an individual liable under an alter ego theory, under Nevada law, the plaintiffs must show: (1) the corporation was influenced and governed by the person asserted to be the alter ego; (2) there is such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts are such that adherence to the corporate fiction of a separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently pled that they made domestic transactions in securities not listed on a domestic exchange.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Blanks v. Fluor Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: The theory of the alter ego has been adopted by the courts to prevent injustice, in those cases where the fiction of a corporate entity has been used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience or to perpetrate a wrong; it should never be invoked to work an injustice, or to give an unfair advantage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company's domination of and control of subsidiaries were insufficient to establish principal-agent relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Hyungkeun Sun
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when three elements are present: (1) the corporation was a mere alter ego of the shareholder, (2) the corporate structure was used to perpetrate a wrong, and (3) piercing the corporate veil would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from creditors' investment with debtors was nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Howland
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Lexington Division.
Headnote: To successfully pierce corporate veil under Kentucky law, plaintiff must prove loss of separate entity existence and an injustice beyond mere inability to collect debt from corporation; however, proof of actual fraud is not required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could not reverse veil-pierce in support of fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Geanacopulos v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nevada courts will find a corporate defendant liable under an alter ego theory if the plaintiff proves three factors by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Tort Liability. Patient sufficiently alleged that licensor and sub-licensor of drug counseling facility's trademark were responsible his mistreatment under alter ego or agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Simons v. Ditto Trade, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law governing the alter ego doctrine, plaintiff must plead both a unity of interest and ownership, and facts which show that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Former chief executive officer failed to state claims for securities fraud and control person liability under Securities Exchange Age.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Winderting Investments, LLC v. Furnell
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: To justify the issuance of a rule directing individual stockholders to show cause why they should not be held personally accountable for the corporation's debts, there should be a preliminary showing that the corporation is in actuality the alter ego of the stockholders and that it was organized or after organization was employed by the stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes, or in some fashion that the corporate property was converted or the corporate assets depleted for the personal benefit of the individual stockholders, or that the corporate structure was not bona fidely established or, in general, that property belonging to the corporation can be traced into the hands of the stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Discovery. Judgment creditors failed to show that nonparty was alter ego of judgment creditor and, thus, were not entitled to financial discovery from nonparty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Soule v. High Rock Holding, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nevada courts apply the alter ego doctrine where the following requirements are met: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice; it is not necessary that the plaintiff prove actual fraud, rather, it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. The Bankruptcy Court abused its discretion in denying a creditor's request for additional time for discovery under summary judgment rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Soule v. High Rock Holding, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Reliance or reasonable expectation of payment from an alter ego at the time of transaction is not a necessary requirement for application of the alter ego doctrine under Nevada law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. The Bankruptcy Court abused its discretion in denying a creditor's request for additional time for discovery under summary judgment rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Soule v. High Rock Holding, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, the purpose of the alter ego doctrine is to "do justice" whenever it appears that the protections provided by the corporate form are being abused; there is no litmus test for determining when the corporate fiction should be disregarded, and the result depends on the circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. The Bankruptcy Court abused its discretion in denying a creditor's request for additional time for discovery under summary judgment rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: A.V.E.L.A., Inc. v. Estate of Monroe
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law allows the corporate veil to be pierced either when there is fraud or when the corporation has been used as an alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Neither undue delay, undue prejudice, nor futility precluded granting of a motion to amend a counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Federal Resources Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, the corporate veil may be pierced when (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such corporation and such person has ceased and (2) it appears from the facts that the observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Response action taken by government under CERCLA was consistent with national contingency plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Test of alter ego status is flexible, and, although perhaps a germane or sufficient basis for imposing alter ego status, an anti-union animus or an intent to evade union obligations, such as those in a collective bargaining agreement (CBA), is not a necessary factor to impose alter ego liability; relatedly, parallel existence also is not an impediment to imposing alter ego status.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Trustees of multiemployer plan could amend pleading to join defendants to hold them liable under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: California law recognizes alter ego liability where two conditions are met: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Transferee was nominee of taxpayer, for purposes of enforcing federal tax lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Lester v. Career Building Academy
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division I.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, the trial court must find that the corporate entity is a mere instrumentality for the transaction of the shareholders' own affairs, and there is such unity of interest in ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Attorney Fees. Case law factors for award of fees to prevailing employer in a Wage Claim Act action do not apply to determine award of fees to prevailing employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: Georgia courts will disregard the corporate form if a corporation is a mere alter ego or business conduit of a person and the corporate form was used as a subterfuge so that to observe it would work an injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's allegations stated a fraud claim against LLC that owned debtor and debtor's president under Georgia Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: To prevail under an alter-ego theory of liability under Georgia law, the plaintiff must show that the shareholders disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's allegations stated a fraud claim against LLC that owned debtor and debtor's president under Georgia Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: To show that the shareholders disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs, as required to prevail under alter-ego theory of liability under Georgia law, the plaintiff must generally establish evidence of fraud, abuse of the corporate form, commingling of assets or corporate insolvency at the time of the transaction.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's allegations stated a fraud claim against LLC that owned debtor and debtor's president under Georgia Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: William v. AES Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, a court can pierce the corporate veil only upon showing that: (1) the corporation was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the other entity, and (2) the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Alien Tort Statute did not give court jurisdiction over customers' claims against Cameroonian power company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: William v. AES Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce the corporate veil on an alter ego theory, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Alien Tort Statute did not give court jurisdiction over customers' claims against Cameroonian power company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: William v. AES Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Alter ego liability may attach when there is such unity between a corporation and an individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Alien Tort Statute did not give court jurisdiction over customers' claims against Cameroonian power company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Iantosca v. Benistar Administrative Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, determination that corporation was its principal's alter ego did not require finding that it was sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Privileges. Corporate officers' invocation of Fifth Amendment permitted jury to draw adverse inference against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: United States ex rel. Landis v. Tailwind Sports Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Courts apply a two-pronged test when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, evaluating several factors by grouping them into two questions: (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator and government stated claim against former lead rider of professional cycling team under reverse false claims provision of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Hasso v. Hapke
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In California, two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Trustee could not reasonably rely on any material misrepresentations about hedge fund investment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wandering Trails, LLC v. Big Bite Excavation, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2014 Term.
Headnote: To prove that a company is the alter ego of a member of the company, a claimant must demonstrate (1) a unity of interest and ownership to a degree that the separate personalities of the company and individual no longer exist and (2) if the acts are treated as acts of the company an inequitable result would follow.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues of alter ego and veil-piercing claims are equitable questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Cornerstone Healthcare Group Holding, Inc. v. Reliant Splitter, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: One basis for piercing the corporate veil is the "alter ego doctrine," which applies when there is such unity between a corporation and an individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and asserting jurisdiction over only the corporation would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Owners of parent company that owned Texas business did not purposefully avail themselves of privilege of conducting activities in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Stewart v. Bureaus Inv. Group No. 1, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alabama law provides that a corporation may be an alter-ego of a person or another entity, and that the corporate veil may be pierced when evidence establishes that to be the case.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Statute of limitations for Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and state law claims were not equitably tolled by alleged fraudulent concealment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Nieto-Vincenty v. Valledor
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: In certain circumstances under Puerto Rico law, the corporate veil may be pierced and individual liability imposed upon the individuals for which the corporate entity served merely as an alter ego. 14 L.P.R.A. § 3501 et seq.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Personal Injury. Vessel passenger's wife was not in zone of danger, as required to establish admiralty claim for NIED.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Accurso v. Infra-Red Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, under the "alter ego" corporate veil piercing subtheory, which is applicable when the individual or corporate owner controls the corporation to be pierced and the controlling owner is to be held liable, the party that seeks to pierce the corporate veil must show that the lack of corporate formalities led to some misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Term Company in independent contractor agreement referred only to corporation, and did not personally bind corporation's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Llewellyn-Jones v. Metro Property Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, an alter ego claim is based on the equitable doctrine that courts may sometimes disregard the formalities of business structures when those structures are misused for the purpose of avoiding a company's legal obligations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine did not apply to bar investors' fraudulent inducement claim against sellers of sham investments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: VFS Financing, Inc. v. Falcon Fifty LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a court can pierce the corporate veil of an entity where there is fraud or where a subsidiary is in fact a mere instrumentality or alter ego of its owner.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Purchaser of aircraft sufficiently alleged that its alleged breaches of security agreement governing loan were not material.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: VFS Financing, Inc. v. Falcon Fifty LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To prevail under the alter-ego theory of piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, a plaintiff need not prove that there was actual fraud but must show (1) a mingling of the operations of the entity and its owner, and (2) an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Purchaser of aircraft sufficiently alleged that its alleged breaches of security agreement governing loan were not material.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Buckley v. Abuzir
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will pierce the corporate veil where (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors were not required to show that controller was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Xiotech Corp. v. Express Data Products Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the doctrine of alter ego or piercing the corporate veil liability permits the owner of a corporation or a corporate affiliate, under certain limited circumstances, to be held liable for the corporation's obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold CEO, who owned controlling interest in corporation, liable for corporation's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Sandoval v. Ali
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: "Equitable alter ego doctrine," which governs whether two separate entities may be treated as the same entity under California law, applies where (1) such a unity of interest and ownership exists that the personalities of the corporation and individual are no longer separate, and (2) an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Res judicata did not bar employees' putative class claims against employers, alleging violations FLSA and California's Unfair Competition Law (UCL).

Title: Trinity Industries Leasing Company v. Midwest Gas Storage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, plaintiff must allege that the corporate structure causes fraud or similar injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. lessor alleged with sufficient particularity affirmative misrepresentations by the lessee's chief executive officer (CEO).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Trinity Industries Leasing Company v. Midwest Gas Storage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, corporation need not have been created with fraud or unfairness in mind, nor must plaintiff prove actual fraud, so long as it shows a mingling of the operations of the corporation and its owner plus an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. lessor alleged with sufficient particularity affirmative misrepresentations by the lessee's chief executive officer (CEO).

Title: Webmediabrands, Inc. v. Latinvision, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: As a general rule, claims involving alter ego liability are fact-laden and not well suited for summary judgment resolution.

Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In the District of Columbia, generally, the corporate entity will be respected, but a party may be permitted to pierce the corporate veil upon proof, that there is: (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Complaint stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, the alter ego doctrine is not a separate basis for piercing the corporate veil, but is rather subsumed in the notion of paramount equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil when the corporation, rather than being a distinct, responsible entity, is in fact the alter ego or business conduit of the person in control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Complaint stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Seghers v. LaPlace Equipment Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Before the corporate entity is disregarded on the basis it is simply the alter ego of the member, proof of fraud or deceit is usually required; the corporate entity may also be disregarded when the individualities of the corporation and member cease to exist.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Shelby County.
Headnote: The "veil" of the corporation can be "pierced" and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds in exceptional circumstances when the shareholders use the corporation for criminal or fraudulent purposes to the detriment of a third party; in those exceptional circumstances, the courts treat the corporation as a mere "alter ego" of the shareholder, thereby rendering the shareholder liable for the obligations of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil in action against construction company and its owner.

Title: Freilich v. Green Energy Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: To prove alter ego relationship exists between corporation and individual, plaintiff must show that there is such unity between corporation and individual that separateness of corporation has ceased and holding only corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Corporation's principal's answer was ineffective with regard to corporation, but effective with regard to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Dodd v. Savino
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego" doctrine, as exception to general rule that the owner of a corporation is not liable for the contractual obligations of his corporation, applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Glassell Producing Co., Inc. v. Jared Resources, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: "Alter-ego doctrine" permits piercing of the corporate veil when there is a unity between the corporation and the individual such that the corporation's separateness has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would be unjust.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Fraud-related tort claims against operator of oil and gas interests fell within scope of arbitration clause.

Title: Glassell Producing Co., Inc. v. Jared Resources, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate veil can be pierced based on proof that the corporation is an alter ego.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Fraud-related tort claims against operator of oil and gas interests fell within scope of arbitration clause.

Title: In re JMK Construction Group, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability is one basis for piercing the corporate veil under New York law.
