Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Dry Handy Investments, Ltd. v. Corvina Shipping Co. S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine may be used to hold shareholders liable for the debts of their corporation through traditional veil piercing, to hold a corporation liable for the debts of a sole shareholder through reverse veil piercing, or to hold parent, subsidiary, or affiliate corporations liable for the debts of another corporation.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Alter ego relationship with claimant of attached ship was not shown.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Panthera Rail Car LLC v. Kasgro Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, alter-ego liability is an equitable doctrine that is applied with the trial court's discretion, and can be used to reach the controlled entity's assets.
Document Preview: TORTS - Choice of Law. California had a stronger interest in applying its law than Pennsylvania in fraud, civil conspiracy and unfair competition action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Palisades at West Paces Imaging Center, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: In order to justify disregarding corporate entity as alter ego under Georgia law, plaintiff must show that principals disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs, that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and its owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Concealed payments for no consideration were avoidable as actually fraudulent to creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Palisades at West Paces Imaging Center, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil, or finding that company is alter ego of individual, is justified under Georgia law where owner treats company and himself as one unit, or where owner uses corporate funds for personal expenses.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Concealed payments for no consideration were avoidable as actually fraudulent to creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, the aggrieved party must show that the corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the State.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Investors in corporation never became shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Kubican v. The Tavern, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To "pierce the corporate veil" in order to hold a corporation's shareholders actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable, a two-prong test applies: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and of the individual shareholders no longer exist, i.e., a disregard of formalities requirement, and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, i.e., a fairness requirement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Uniform Limited Liability Company (LLC) Act permits equitable remedy of piercing the veil to be asserted against an LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Columbia Asset Recovery Group, LLC v. Kelly
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory when the corporate entity has been disregarded by the principals themselves so that there is such a unity of ownership and interest that the separateness of the corporation has ceased to exist.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Judgment. Genuine issue of material fact existed regarding whether payment for assignment of debt terminated borrower's obligation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: RMS Titanic, Inc. v. Zaller
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, to establish alter ego doctrine it must be shown that (1) stockholders' disregard of corporate entity made it mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs, (2) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and owners no longer exist, and (3) adherence to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Trade Dress. Plaintiffs involved in staging of museum quality exhibition stated plausible trade dress infringement claim under Lanham Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Gentex Corp. v. Abbott
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The rationale for piercing the corporate veil is that the corporation in question is something less than a bona fide independent entity (a mere alter ego of an individual), that the corporate form is being used to perpetuate fraud, or that corporate formalities have not been properly complied with.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Intellectual Property. A competitor in the market for sale of flight helmets purposefully availed himself of the forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Parenteau
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio's alter ego doctrine, where the stock of a corporation is owned entirely by one party, and the party in interest is the stockholder, the fiction of the separate entity of the corporation may be disregarded where the ends of justice require it.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Forfeitures. Company, the claimant in ancillary proceeding following preliminary order of criminal forfeiture, was alter ego of defendant and thus, its interest in insurance policies purchased by defendant was forfeited to government.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re SK Foods, LP
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California, Sacramento Division.
Headnote: To establish that one entity is the alter ego of another under California law, plaintiff must show (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Substantive consolidation of related entities with Chapter 11 debtors' estates was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re SK Foods, LP
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California, Sacramento Division.
Headnote: When owners of an entity use their control to siphon off corporate assets to benefit owners or related entities and nothing is given in return, that conduct is deemed to be inequitable under California's alter ego analysis, because it harms the interests of the corporation and its creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Substantive consolidation of related entities with Chapter 11 debtors' estates was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: American Action Network, Inc. v. Cater America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under Wyoming's "alter ego doctrine," when evidence is presented that adherence to the fiction of the separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, courts will disregard the separate entity and hold shareholders individually liable to third parties for damages caused by the corporation's acts.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise specific personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendants in contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taylor v. Bettis
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Southern Division.
Headnote: The equitable doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is recognized in North Carolina and has been implemented through the instrumentality rule, according to which a corporate entity that is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the state will be disregarded.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Colorado River abstention was not warranted when allegedly parallel state court actions had concluded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Metroplex Mailing Services, LLC v. RR Donnelley & Sons Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence that a company was used as an alter ego does not, by itself, create an issue regarding whether it was used to commit an actual fraud on the plaintiff for the defendant's personal benefit that would allow the plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. President of LLC could not be found individually liable without showing that he benefited personally from sale of equipment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Reuter
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" fastens liability on individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his own personal business, and such liability arises from fraud or injustice perpetrated not on the corporation but on third persons dealing with the corporation; corporate form may be disregarded only where equity requires the action to assist a third party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor's powers as co-trustee of revocable trusts were estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Reuter
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, individual will be deemed to be the alter ego of a corporation when (1) the individual completely dominates and controls the finances, policy, and business practice of the corporation, (2) such control was for an improper purpose, such as fraud or wrong, or an unjust act in contravention of a third party's legal rights, and (3) alter ego's control of the corporation caused injury to the third party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor's powers as co-trustee of revocable trusts were estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Houng
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, one of the prerequisites to a finding of alter ego liability is that the corporate form must have been used to perpetrate a fraud or accomplish some other inequitable purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Arbitrator necessarily decided that debtor breached a fiduciary duty owed to judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tommy Lee Handbags Mfg. Ltd. v. 1948 Corp.

Headnote: Showing of fraud or wrongdoing is not necessary to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory under Delaware law.

Title: World Class Const. Management Group v. Baylor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: District of Columbia law allows plaintiffs to pierce the corporate veil rarely and on a case-by-case basis when the facts demonstrate that there is: (1) unity of ownership and interest and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.

Title: Brown Bark III, L.P. v. Haver
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Although the showings required to invoke the alter ego doctrine and the successor liability doctrine are different, their effect is the same.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brown Bark III, L.P. v. Haver
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In California, two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist; and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Attorney Fees. Unilateral attorney fee provision was not made reciprocal by statute to extent that it applied to tort claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Disciplinary Proceeding Against McGrath
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: When one person so dominates and controls a corporation that such corporation is the person's alter ego, a court is justified in piercing the veil of a corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Discipline. Disbarment was warranted for attorney who intentionally filed a false claim in a bankruptcy proceeding and attempted ex parte communications with a federal judge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wellness Intern. Network, Ltd. v. Sharif
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, there are two showings that must be made to establish that a corporation is merely an alter ego: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances must be such that an adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Litigant may not waive objection to bankruptcy court's constitutional authority to enter final judgment in core proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the alter ego doctrine requires proof of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Attorney Fees. Patentee's infringement suit was exceptional, warranting award of attorney fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: A corporations' owner may be held liable where it is established that: (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, such that it is an alter ego of the corporation, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A shareholder of a corporation did not exercise dominion and control over the corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: An individual controls a corporation to the extent that it may be considered an alter ego when the individual conducts business for personal purposes, rather than to further the business of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A shareholder of a corporation did not exercise dominion and control over the corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Alonso v. Blackstone Financial Group LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, whether the corporate veil will be pierced is dependent on the circumstances of each case, but there are two general requirements: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Director of debt collection agency was debt collector within meaning of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Blue Whale Corp. v. Grand China Shipping Development Co., Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Choice-of-law clauses in underlying contracts are irrelevant to assessing alter-ego claims.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. On alter ego claim, court was not bound by choice of law provision in charter party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Johnson v. Allied Recycling, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish an alter ego cause of action, or an action to pierce the corporate veil, it must be shown that the shareholders of a corporation disregarded the corporate entity and made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Crimes and Contempt. Judgment creditor, rather than bankruptcy trustee, was proper party to bring fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tap Holdings, LLC v. Orix Finance Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability exists when any abuse of the corporate form is exercised for the purpose of working an inequity on another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Promissory note holders stated a claim against maker's lenders based on piercing the corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, veil-piercing and alter ego doctrines are logically and legally distinguishable: while veil-piercing always requires proof of some wrong or fraud as well as injury, alter ego finding formally recognizes what was a preexisting fact, that at time of relevant transaction, one or more controlling principals and one or more corporations were in actuality one and the same person, the former inseparable from the latter and its liability both personal and direct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to provide sufficient explanation for record-keeping lapses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Consequence of alter ego determination is not simply the imposition of personal liability on principal for obligations of the dominated corporation; rather, since corporate alter ego both lacked an existence separate from person who controlled it and functioned as less than a bona fide independent entity, acts of the corporation are actually acts of the controlling individual.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to provide sufficient explanation for record-keeping lapses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: While principal might have initially adhered to state law requirements for creating a legally valid corporation, an alter ego finding compels court to regard corporation as devoid of genuine independence and to attribute responsibility for its actions to the one true "person," whether a natural or artificial entity, who directed its affairs.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to provide sufficient explanation for record-keeping lapses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, where a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: In California, common principles apply regardless of whether the alleged alter ego is based on piercing the corporate veil to attach liability to a shareholder or to hold a corporation liable as part of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Because it is founded on equitable principles, application of the alter ego doctrine is not made to depend upon prior decisions involving factual situations which appear to be similar, and it is the general rule that the conditions under which a corporate entity may be disregarded vary according to the circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Swan v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois law permits piercing of the corporate veil when two separate prongs are met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Swan v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago

Headnote: The Illinois corporate veil-piercing doctrine requires the parties to have a unity of interest and ownership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McDaniel v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The Illinois corporate veil-piercing doctrine requires the parties to have a unity of interest and ownership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, courts considering whether to pierce the corporate veil to impose liability on individual shareholders assess: (1) the extent to which the corporation is merely the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) whether justice requires piercing the corporate veil based on the fact that the corporate fiction was a means of perpetuating a fraud or defeating a rightful claim; and (3) whether an equitable result will be achieved by piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, an "alter ego" relationship exists when the corporation is a mere instrumentality for the transaction of the shareholders' own affairs, and there is such unity of interest in ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Activities of LLC's predecessor could be used to establish personal jurisdiction over LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Colorado law, plaintiff must show that: (1) the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) justice requires the veil to be pierced because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim and to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties; and (3) an equitable result will be achieved by holding the shareholder personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Activities of LLC's predecessor could be used to establish personal jurisdiction over LLC.

Title: Hill v. Fairfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil and declare a stockholder or officer the corporation's alter ego when evidence is present that the stockholder or officer used the corporate form to escape personal liability.

Title: Patel v. Flexo Converters U.S.A., Inc.

Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Supervisor was not employer's alter ego for purposes of alter ego exception to exclusivity of workers' compensation law for intentional torts committed by supervisory employee who is alter ego of employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Patel v. Flexo Converters U.S.A., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Standard for piercing the corporate veil requires that the corporation, functionally speaking, have no separate existence from the alter ego who controls and dominates the corporation's affairs.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Supervisor was not employer's alter ego for purposes of alter ego exception to exclusivity of workers' compensation law for intentional torts committed by supervisory employee who is alter ego of employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Florida law, veil piercing is most commonly used by a creditor seeking to pursue a corporation's shareholder where (1) the corporate shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of the corporation, (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporation caused injury to the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtors could not claim tool of trade exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company.

Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, "reverse veil piercing" does not require a fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form; instead, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show (1) the shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation, and (2) that no creditors would be prejudiced by the reverse veil piercing.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtors could not claim tool of trade exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company.

Title: In re Huber
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Washington, at Tacoma.
Headnote: Washington recognizes alter ego doctrine in context of corporations, and if private person so dominates and controls corporation that corporation is his alter ego, then court is justified in piercing corporate veil and holding that corporation and private person are one and the same.

Title: No Cost Conference, Inc. v. Windstream Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: In California, before the doctrine of alter ego liability may be invoked, two elements must be alleged: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Conference calling services provider sufficiently alleged successor liability against telecommunications carrier.

Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, in addition to piercing the corporate veil, a court may also use the corporate "alter ego" doctrine to disregard the corporate form and hold individuals personally liable.

Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, in the absence of a causal connection between the alleged misuse of the corporate form and harm suffered, an "alter ego" claim to disregard the corporate form and hold individuals personally liable cannot be sustained.

Title: Beltran v. Vincent P. Miraglia, M.D., P.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Three factors must be proven to "pierce the corporate veil" and hold an individual shareholder liable for the debts of the corporation: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Pleading. Mid-trial amendment of complaint to add professional association as a defendant did not relate back to original complaint.

Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Even under federal common law, courts will veil-pierce only in extraordinary circumstances, and must find either fraud or that a defendant so dominated and disregarded its alter ego's corporate form that the alter ego was actually carrying on the controlling party's business instead of its own.

Title: Jurista v. Amerinox Processing, Inc.

Title: Jurista v. Amerinox Processing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, to satisfy first element required to pierce the corporate veil, namely, that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, plaintiff must show that the controlled corporation acted robot or puppet-like in mechanical response to the controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Disbursing agent stated claim for actual fraudulent transfers against debtor's officers and directors.

Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.

Headnote: Under Louisiana law, proof of actual fraud is not required to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine; however, if allegations of fraud are absent, a party bears a heavy burden of proving that the shareholders disregarded the corporate entity to such an extent that it ceased to become distinguishable from themselves.

Title: James v. Duquesne University

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in order to establish personal liability under the alter ego theory, the one seeking to pierce the separate entity's existence must show the person or entity in control of a corporation used that control, or used the corporate assets, to further his its own personal interests.

Title: U.S. v. Cohen

Headnote: In comparison to the nominee theory, the alter ego theory focuses more on facts which suggest that the corporate form is being disregarded and that piercing the corporate veil may be appropriate, and specifically reverse piercing.

Title: Timber Integrated Investments, LLC v. Welch
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: The court employs the instrumentality rule to determine whether to disregard the corporate entity and hold parent or affiliated corporations or shareholders liable for the acts of a corporation; this rule provides that the corporate entity will be disregarded and the corporation and the shareholder treated as one and the same person, it being immaterial whether the sole or dominant shareholder is an individual or another corporation, if that corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the State.

Title: My Father's House No. 1 v. McCardle

Title: Ransom v. VFS, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, an officer and shareholder of a corporation cannot be held personally liable for the obligations of the corporation except in limited circumstances, which include: (1) when the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder and piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice; (2) when the officer has personally guaranteed the corporation's obligations; and (3) when the officer has actually participated in misdeeds of the corporation.

Title: In re Archdiocese of Milwaukee
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the "instrumentality" or "alter ego" doctrine requires proof of the following elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the complained of injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Committee failed to state colorable claim for substantive consolidation.

Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: While there is a presumption that the corporate entity and not its shareholders is held liable for corporate acts, the corporate veil may be pierced and shareholders held liable either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by the dominating entity that leads to a wrong against third parties, and thus, a showing of complete control, that is, a shareholder acting as the alter ego of the corporation, standing alone, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil, but rather, that control must have been used to perpetrate fraud or other wrong that resulted in unjust loss or injury.

Headnote: Under New Jersey law, individual may be liable for corporate obligations if he was using corporation as his alter ego and abusing corporate form in order to advance his personal interests.

Title: In re Juve
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Minnesota courts apply two-part test in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on corporate shareholder, under which they first consider whether corporation is alter ego or mere instrumentality of shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: The corporate form normally insulates shareholders, officers, and directors from liability for corporate obligations; however, the corporate veil may be pierced on an alter ego theory where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego theory for piercing the corporate veil applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice; it is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: A corporation's officers are not jointly liable for a corporation's obligations under an alter ego theory merely because they were part of a single business enterprise, i.e., merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; rather, disregarding the corporate structure under an alter ego theory involves two considerations: (1) the relationship between the officers and the corporation and (2) whether the officer's use of the corporation's limited liability was illegitimate. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and impose liability under an alter ego theory of liability, a plaintiff must show: (1) that the persons or entities on whom he seeks to impose liability are alter egos of the debtor, and (2) that the corporate fiction was used for an illegitimate purpose. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: The factors used to determine whether persons or corporate entities sought to be charged with liability are alter egos of the primary debtor are almost entirely irrelevant to whether the use of limited liability was illegitimate, as required to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil: that determination is made based on a careful evaluation of the policies supporting the principle of limited liability. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Last Time Beverage Corp. v. F & V Distribution Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil or limited liability company (LLC) veil will be pierced to achieve an equitable result, among other instances, when a corporation or LLC has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Trade usage testimony was admissible in action for breach of soft-drink distributorship agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Johnson v. Diamond Shine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Bowling Green Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, a court proceeding under theory of alter ego must resolve two dispositive elements: (1) domination of a corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Kentucky court had personal jurisdiction over Ohio defendant in breach of contract suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Steffner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, analysis for alter ego liability is the same as that for claims seeking piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of limited liability company was not warranted under Tennessee law

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: NuCal Foods, Inc. v. Quality Egg LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: To make a prima facie showing of alter ego liability under California law, a plaintiff must allege two elements: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Assertion of personal jurisdiction over other related entities would not have been consistent with due process.

Title: NuCal Foods, Inc. v. Quality Egg LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine under California law is that justice be done.

Title: Allegheny Energy Supply Co., LLC v. Wolf Run Min. Co.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: An exception to the general rule that the corporate entity should be recognized and upheld is the alter ego theory which requires proof (1) that the party exercised domination and control over corporation, and (2) that injustice will result if corporate fiction is maintained despite unity of interests between corporation and its principal.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Underperformance by seller of coal was not excused by the terms of force majeure clause.

Title: Bank of Montreal v. SK Foods, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To establish a party as the alter ego of a corporation under California law, applicant must show both (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Transfer or dismissal of action related to substantive consolidation proceeding before bankruptcy court was not warranted.

Title: Bank of Montreal v. SK Foods, LLC

Headnote: Under California law, one requirement of test for alter ego liability is that adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or work an injustice to a third person.

Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Financial courses developer was not required to produce evidence of more than one of the Colman factors to survive corporate officers' motion for summary judgment on developers' alter ego claim; a strong showing on a single factor could have satisfied both elements of the "Norman alter ego test," under which (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, viz., the corporation is, in fact, the alter ego of one or a few individuals, and (2) the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.

Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.

Title: In re Hoffmann
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Minnesota courts apply two-part test in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil in order to hold corporate shareholder liable for corporation's debt, pursuant to which they first consider whether corporation is alter ego or mere instrumentality of shareholder, and then decide whether declining to pierce corporate veil will result in injustice or fundamental unfairness; both prongs of test must be satisfied in order to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Sellers justifiably relied on representations contradicted by close, lawyerly reading of closing documents.

Title: Mama's Enterprises, LLC v. U.S.

Headnote: Alabama law provides that a corporation may be the alter-ego of a person or another entity, and that the corporate veil may be pierced when evidence establishes that to be the case.

Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil on alter ego theory under Kentucky law, plaintiff must prove: (1) that corporation is not only influenced by its owners, but that there is such unity of ownership and interest that their separateness has ceased, and (2) that facts are such that adherence to normal attributes of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Mbahaba v. Morgan
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: The Supreme Court will pierce the corporate veil and assess individual liability where the owners have used the company to promote an injustice or fraud upon the plaintiff; in such a case, the Court will disregard the fiction that the corporation is independent of its stockholders and treat the stockholders as the corporation's alter egos.

Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Treating a corporation as the alter ego of another entity is the same thing as piercing the corporate veil; it comes down to disregarding the corporation's separate existence in order to avoid injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: A two-prong test is employed to determine whether federal common law supports piercing the corporate veil: (1) whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Restitution. A nonprofit corporation was the defendant's alter ego, and thus was not entitled to restitution from the defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: The doctrine of alter ego is brought to bear only upon a showing not merely of single ownership of a corporation, or of deliberate adoption and use of a corporate form in order to secure its legitimate advantages, but of such domination of a corporation as in reality to negate its separate personality in circumstances in which at some innocent party's expense, the corporation is converted into such an instrumentality with the result that the corporate identity is disregarded as the justice of the case may require.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Restitution. A nonprofit corporation was the defendant's alter ego, and thus was not entitled to restitution from the defendant.

Title: TransFresh Corp. v. Ganzerla & Assoc., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, an individual who is found to be an alter-ego of a corporation may be held liable for statements of the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Lanham Act claims sounded in fraud, so were required to be pled with heightened particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois law permits corporate-veil piercing when two separate prongs are met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, when determining whether a unity of interest and ownership exists, as required to pierce the corporate veil, court considers whether the following factors are present: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) failure to pay dividends; (5) corporate insolvency; (6) nonfunctioning corporate officers; (7) missing corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets to owner or other entity to creditor detriment; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationship among related entities; and (11) whether corporation is mere façade for a dominant owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Commissioner of Environmental Protection v. State Five Indus. Park, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Identity rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in addition to a unity of interest between an insider and his corporations, that permitting a corporate defendant to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise through adherence to the concept of its separate existence would serve only to defeat justice and equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of reverse veil piercing was unwarranted under instrumentality rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California law, while a corporation is ordinarily regarded as a legal entity separate and distinct from its stockholders, officers and directors, that presumption may be challenged under the alter ego doctrine where a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrong or inequitable purpose.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate officer at massage corporation was not massage therapists' employer within meaning of FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine prevents individuals or other corporations from misusing the corporate laws by the device of a sham corporate entity formed for the purpose of committing fraud or other misdeeds.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate officer at massage corporation was not massage therapists' employer within meaning of FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine allows a court to disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate officer at massage corporation was not massage therapists' employer within meaning of FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: While there is no specific litmus test for determining whether an individual is an alter ego of a corporate entity, California imposes two general requirements: (1) that there be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate officer at massage corporation was not massage therapists' employer within meaning of FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Watson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky, Bowling Green Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporate veil may be pierced under "alter ego" or "instrumentality" theories.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Corporate veil could not be pierced to create debt that could be excepted from discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Watson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky, Bowling Green Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil on "alter ego" theory under Kentucky law, plaintiff must prove: (1) that corporation was not only influenced by its owners, but that there was such a unity of ownership and interest that their separateness ceased to exist, and (2) that recognizing a separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Corporate veil could not be pierced to create debt that could be excepted from discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: MedChoice Financial, LLC v. ADS Alliance Data Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego liability exists under Ohio law where: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Economic loss rule did not bar credit card issuer's fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brennan's Inc. v. Colbert
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: One of those exceptions where the court may ignore the corporate fiction and find the shareholders personally liable for the debts of a corporation is where the corporation is found to be the alter ego of the shareholder; it usually involves situations where fraud or deceit has been practiced by the shareholder through the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could not pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for the debts of the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Rapid Settlements, Ltd.'s Application for Approval of Transfer of Structured Settlement Payment Rights
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3.
Headnote: Washington recognizes the "alter ego" doctrine, providing where one entity so dominates and controls a corporation that such corporation is the entity's alter ego, a court is justified in piercing the veil of corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Settlements. Settlement obligor could receive offset for attorney fee judgment it had obtained against transferee of settlement payment rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Inter-Tel Technologies, Inc. v. Linn Station Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: A court may proceed under the traditional alter ego formulation or the instrumentality theory, when determining whether to pierce a corporate veil, because the tests are essentially interchangeable. KRS 271B.6–220(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual fraud not required in order to pierce veil of tenant which was retail branch for parent and grandparent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Inter-Tel Technologies, Inc. v. Linn Station Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: Both the alter ego formulation and the instrumentality theory of piercing a corporate veil resolves to two dispositive elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice. KRS 271B.6–220(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual fraud not required in order to pierce veil of tenant which was retail branch for parent and grandparent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Fernbach, LLC v. Calleo
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate judgment debtor's corporate veil could not be pierced to hold brother of debtor's sole shareholder personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Clipper Wonsild Tankers Holding A/S v. Biodiesel Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under the federal common law standard, a plaintiff must show that an alter ego was used to perpetrate a fraud or was so dominated and its corporate form so disregarded that the alter ego primarily transacted another entity's business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Judgment. Fact issue as to whether judgment debtor was alter ego of provider of energy management services precluded summary judgment in maritime action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Clipper Wonsild Tankers Holding A/S v. Biodiesel Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Veil piercing determinations are fact specific and differ with the circumstances of each case; thus, the alter ego determination must be made in view of the totality of the facts.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Judgment. Fact issue as to whether judgment debtor was alter ego of provider of energy management services precluded summary judgment in maritime action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Van Maanen v. Youth With a Mission-Bishop
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego doctrine provides that corporate identity may be disregarded where abuse of corporate privilege justifies holding equitable ownership of corporation liable for corporation's actions.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Torts. No university-student relationship existed between participant in wilderness leadership training course and university.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Van Maanen v. Youth With a Mission-Bishop
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, there are two elements required to invoke alter ego doctrine: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and its equitable owner that separate personalities of shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be inequitable result if acts in question are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Torts. No university-student relationship existed between participant in wilderness leadership training course and university.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Hotels Nevada, LLC v. L.A. Pacific Center, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Under Nevada or California law, in order to apply the alter ego doctrine and pierce the corporate veil: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Arbitration. Arbitration panel did not exceed its powers in proceeding during one arbitrator's medical absence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Swinerton Builders v. Nassi
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: A corporation is a shareholder's alter ego when the corporation is a mere instrumentality for the transaction of the shareholder's own affairs, and there is such a unity of interest in ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder no longer exist.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate president was liable for attorney fees incurred by creditor as result of veil piercing.

Title: Christopher v. Sinyard
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where those who own or control a corporation have brought about such a unity of interest and ownership as between themselves and the corporation, the unpaid corporate creditor may pierce the corporate veil and look to them for satisfaction of the corporation's debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted disregard of home builder's corporate entity and piercing corporate veil to permit recovery against officers.

Title: Soroof Trading Development Co., Ltd. v. GE Fuel Cell Systems, LLC

Headnote: Delaware law permits a court to pierce the corporate veil where there is fraud or where corporation is in fact a mere instrumentality or alter ego of its owner.

Headnote: Ohio law recognizes alter ego theory to disregard corporate fiction, but not reverse veil-piercing principles.

Title: In re Zhang
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division,
Headnote: Veil-piercing and alter ego concepts are distinct: the former asks court to hold A vicariously liable for B's debts, while the latter asserts that A and B are same entity, such that liability is direct.

Title: Giron v. Dodds
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: A party seeking to disregard the corporate entity must prove by affirmative evidence that there is (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong.

Title: Informatics Applications Group, Inc. v. Shkolnikov
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, a court can pierce the corporate veil only upon a showing that: (1) the corporation was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the other entity, and (2) the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.

Title: Union Ins. Co. v. Hull & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, courts may disregard the corporate form under the alter ego doctrine if the entity is merely an instrumentality or device set up to ensure the avoidance of the legal obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Union Ins. Co. v. Hull & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, a corporate entity is the alter ego of a person if (1) the person influences and governs the entity; (2) a unity of interest and ownership exists such that the corporate entity and the person cannot be separated; and (3) giving legal effect to the fictional separation between the corporate entity and the person would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Arbitration and Appraisal. Dispute between insurer and insurance agency did not fall within the scope of an arbitration provision.

Title: S.E.C. v. Woolf
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Utah law, a court may pierce the corporate veil and hold individuals liable if the corporate entity is found to be the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the individuals sought to be held personally liable and a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.

Title: S.E.C. v. Woolf
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, alter ego theory sufficient to pierce corporate veil must be supported by a showing that: (1) the individual and the corporation were united by interest and ownership, and (2) the individual used the corporation to evade a personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or a crime, to commit an injustice, or to gain an unfair advantage.

Title: In re ClassicStar Mare Lease Litigation

Headnote: The alter ego formulation required to pierce corporate veil under Kentucky law requires a demonstration: (1) that corporation is not only influenced by owners, but also that there is such unity of ownership and interest that their separateness has ceased; and (2) the facts are such that an adherence to normal attributes of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Federal common-law test for piercing the corporate veil proceeds in two steps, asking (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
