Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Although, previously, Texas law allowed for the corporate veil to be pierced under three expansive categories, namely, where the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, where the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and where the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, a litigant seeking to pierce the corporate veil for breach of contract now must also prove that the defendant shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate an actual fraud on the obligee primarily for the direct personal benefit of the shareholder. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of corporation controlled by debtor failed to establish actual fraud, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Misik v. D'Arco
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: To determine whether the facts are such that adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of a corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, as would support application of the alter ego doctrine, the test is that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, it will produce an unjust or inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of alter ego allegation in lawsuit did not preclude amendment of judgment to add alter ego judgment debtor.

Title: Misik v. D'Arco
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine does not require proof of fraud, and can be satisfied by evidence that adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would promote injustice or bring about inequitable results.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of alter ego allegation in lawsuit did not preclude amendment of judgment to add alter ego judgment debtor.

Title: Barker v. A.D. Conner Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Unlawful motive or intent are critical inquiries in an alter ego analysis.

Title: State ex rel. DeWine v. S & R Recycling, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: For purposes of test to determine whether corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable, requirement of control over the corporation by those to be held liable is a concise statement of the alter ego doctrine; to succeed a plaintiff must show that the individual and the corporation are fundamentally indistinguishable.

Title: State ex rel. DeWine v. S & R Recycling, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: In applying the instrumentality or alter ego doctrine, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, the courts are concerned with reality and not form, with how the corporation operated and the individual defendant's relationship to that operation.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) residents' allegations were sufficient to invoke alter ego doctrine for class action claims.

Title: Walsh v. Kindred Healthcare

Headnote: Under California law, to invoke the alter ego doctrine, plaintiffs must allege: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, corporate veil piercing and the alter-ego doctrine have been used to do one thing only: hold owners of corporations liable for the debts of the corporations they own.

Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there are three broad categories of grounds on which a court may pierce the corporate veil: (1) the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, (2) the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and (3) the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil, under Texas law, liability follows if there exists such unity between the corporation and the individual that the corporation ceases to be separate, and holding only the corporation liable would promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil pursuant to alter ego theory must prove that it is necessary to hold the individual liable, as opposed to the corporate form, to avoid a substantial injustice to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wehlage v. EmpRes Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: To avail herself of the alter ego doctrine under California law, a plaintiff must allege two elements: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) resident stated claim against SNF operator for violation of nurse staffing requirement.

Title: In re Xenerga, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, an "alter ego claim" is an action to impose liability on a corporation's principals or related entities where a corporation was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Xenerga, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Florida courts will pierce the corporate veil, pursuant to alter ego claim, upon finding by a preponderance of the evidence that (1) shareholders dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation was in fact nonexistent and shareholders were in fact alter egos of corporation, (2) corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Proposed compromise, which attempted to settle claims that were not estate property, could not be approved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Oginsky v. Paragon Properties of Costa Rica LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, to show that a corporation is the alter ego of a defendant, a plaintiff must allege the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact nonexistent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation.

Headnote: Under Texas law, the corporate veil may be pierced to hold an individual shareholder liable in three broad situations: where (1) the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, (2) the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and (3) the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.

Headnote: Objective in an alter ego claim under Oklahoma law is to pierce the corporate veil of a corporate defendant to reach the assets of the shareholders.

Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC

Headnote: A finding of fact of alter ego, standing alone, creates no cause of action under Oklahoma law; it merely imposes liability against a second corporation or individual upon an underlying cause of action, such as fraud or breach of contract, brought against the first corporation.

Title: Leek v. Cooper

Title: Leek v. Cooper

Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine is not that the individual shareholder becomes the corporation, but that the individual shareholder is liable for the actions of the corporation; for all other purposes, the separate corporate existence remains.

Title: Ruffin v. New Destination, LLC

Title: In re Rood
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Application of the alter ego doctrine to disregard the corporate form requires a showing of (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate a violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for debtor's parents on fraudulent transfer claims.

Title: In re Rood

Headnote: Under Maryland law, alter ego doctrine may be applied where the corporate entity has been used as a subterfuge and to observe it would work an injustice, the rationale being that if the shareholders or the corporations themselves disregard the proper formalities of a corporation, then the law will do likewise as necessary to protect individual and corporate creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for debtor's parents on fraudulent transfer claims.

Title: Capon v. Monopoly Game LLC

Title: Molinos Valle Del Cibao, C. por A. v. Lama

Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik

Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Alter ego allegations did not become the property of the bankruptcy estate once corporate debtor filed for bankruptcy.

Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lake City Janitorial, Inc.

Title: Lentz v. Trinchard
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the "alter ego" doctrine ultimately requires proof of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Headnote: Under Kentucky law, in order to pierce corporate veil on an alter ego theory, plaintiff must prove: (1) that there was such a unity of ownership and interest between corporation and its owners that their separateness ceased to exist; and (2) that recognition of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misuse of company funds was in nature of embezzlement or larceny.

Title: Charter Services, Inc. v. DL Air, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In applying alter ego analysis under Delaware law, courts look to how the corporation operates and the particular party's relationship to that operation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient, under Delaware law, to support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine's first prong requires proof of such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, but the corporation is, instead, the alter ego of one or a few individuals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Two sole shareholders and officers of corporation did not use corporation as facade.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Evidence that may establish the "use as facade" factor in an alter ego analysis includes a failure to distinguish between corporate and personal property, the use of corporate funds to pay personal expenses without proper accounting, and failure to maintain complete corporate and financial records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Two sole shareholders and officers of corporation did not use corporation as facade.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Jarvar
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Montana courts consider two factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the corporation is the alter ego of the individual, and (2) there must be a showing that the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Collateral estoppel did not apply under Montana law to preclude debtor's state-law consumer protection claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Hinds County, Miss. v. Wachovia Bank N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability is an equitable doctrine, and piercing the corporate veil may be appropriate where failing to do so would lead to an inequity.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Conspiracy. Purchasers alleged sufficient facts to plausibly connect investment banking and securities firm to antitrust conspiracy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Gunther v. Capital One, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, a corporation's shareholders will be liable for the acts of the corporation when both (1) the corporate entity was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the individuals sought to be charged personally, and (2) the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Accounts. Checking account holder's account agreement with bank did not incorporate TISA requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, is applicable against individuals, as well as corporations.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Partners Coffee Co., LLC v. Oceana Services and Products Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, a court may pierce the corporate veil under the "alter ego theory" when the corporation or person in control of another organization uses that control, or uses the corporate assets, to further his or her own personal interests.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Gist of the action doctrine did not bar fraud-in-the-inducement counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Partners Coffee Co., LLC v. Oceana Services and Products Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, to succeed on the alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil, the party seeking to establish liability must show that the individual who controlled the corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham; in other words, the complainant must show that the controlled corporation acted robot- or puppet-like in mechanical response to the controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Gist of the action doctrine did not bar fraud-in-the-inducement counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McWilliams Ballard, Inc. v. Level 2 Development
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, "alter ego" theory may be invoked by parties seeking to pierce the corporate veil and impose liability upon the corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Unjust Enrichment. Lender sufficiently alleged unjust enrichment claim arising from use of loan proceeds to purchase real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Penhollow Custom Homes, LLC v. Kim
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine may be applied to pierce the corporate veil if there is a unity between the corporation and the individual to the extent that the corporation's separateness has ceased, and holding only the corporation liable would be unjust. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was not legally sufficient to find that owner of home building corporation was alter ego of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Carlson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, two requirements must be met to disregard the form of the corporate entity and impose personal liability on the shareholder: first, plaintiff must prove a unity of interest and ownership such that separate legal personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and, second, plaintiff must show that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation, an inequitable result would follow or that it would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditor did not justifiably rely on manager's misrepresentation concerning replacement of pick-up truck's converter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, where corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation, and its separate entity so ignored, that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Rood
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is typically applied in Maryland where corporate entity has been used as subterfuge and to observe it would work an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Appeals. No appeal would lie from grant of preliminary injunctive relief to preserve status quo.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Grotenhuis v. County of Santa Barbara
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" arises when a plaintiff comes into court claiming that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests.

Title: Grotenhuis v. County of Santa Barbara
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine, under which the corporate form may be disregarded, is that justice be done.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Shareholder was not entitled to homeowner's property tax exemption on residence owned by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Grotenhuis v. County of Santa Barbara
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: The corporate alter ego theory, which is generally used to prevent a fraud and impute liability, lies only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when the ends of justice so require.

Title: Williams v. Lovell Safety Management Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory for holding the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, a plaintiff must prove: (1) that the corporation is not only influenced by the owners, but also that there is such unity of ownership and interest that their separateness has ceased; and (2) that the facts are such that treatment of the corporation as a separate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To properly plead alter-ego liability under Minnesota law, a plaintiff must meet two requirements: first, it must plead that the relationship between the shareholder and the corporation is such that the corporation was not operated as a separate legal entity; and second, that to shield the shareholder from liability would result in injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: White v. Marshall
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, corporate veil may be pierced only when corporation's affairs are organized, controlled, and conducted so that corporation has no separate existence of its own and is mere instrumentality of shareholders and corporate form is used to evade obligation, gain unjust advantage, or commit injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Carter v. Schuster
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Under veil-piercing and alter ego analysis, unless the facts support the conclusion that there has been a scheme to defraud, the court must recognize and give effect to the general rule that the individual and the corporation are two separate and distinct legal entities.

Title: F.T.C. v. Bronson Partners, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine applies, under Texas law, when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.

Title: Walz v. Martinez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory, courts disregard the corporate entity when there exists such unity between corporation and individual that the corporation ceases to be separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Children of decedent did not purposefully avail selves of activities within Texas to extent supporting exercise of personal jurisdiction.

Title: U.S. S.E.C. v. Levine
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To establish the existence of an alter ego relationship under Nevada law, it must be established that: (1) the corporation was influenced and governed by the person asserted to be the alter ego; (2) there was such unity of interest and ownership that one was inseparable from the other; and (3) adherence to the corporate fiction of a separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Appointment of receiver over defendants' corporate entities was appropriate contempt sanction for violation of injunction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Northern States Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: While corporation is presumed to be separate and distinct from its officers, shareholders, and directors, it may be "alter ego" of another when there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and when adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Corporation that owned real property in trust was nominee of taxpayers for purposes of lien foreclosure action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Northern States Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Term "alter ego" means other self, i.e., where one person or entity acts like, or, for another to extent that they may be considered identical.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Corporation that owned real property in trust was nominee of taxpayers for purposes of lien foreclosure action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: JNS Aviation, Inc. v. Nick Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there are three broad categories in which a court may pierce the corporate veil: (1) the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, (2) the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and (3) the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court properly pierced debtor's corporate veil to hold nondebtor owners liable for judgment debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: To determine whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil, a court must make a three-part inquiry: first, the court must determine whether the corporate entity is the "alter ego" of the person or entity in issue; second, the court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and third, the court must consider whether an equitable result will be achieved by disregarding the corporate form and holding a shareholder or other insider personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. v. Stephens
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Under Montana law, courts may pierce the corporate veil if (1) the corporation is the alter ego of the individual and (2) the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. United States could reach assets of taxpayer's corporations to recover unpaid tax assessments for personal income tax.

Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing corporate veil requires two elements: (1) the corporation is in actuality the alter ego of the stockholders, and (2) it was organized or after organization was employed by the stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes.

Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, shareholder's conduct involving corporation as alleged alter ego may be deemed improper where the corporation was employed for fraudulent or misleading purposes, was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them, or to evade existing personal liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In traditional veil-piercing cases, Minnesota courts apply a two-prong test, with the first prong focusing on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation and the second examining whether piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors that are significant to the inquiry under the first prong of the test for corporate veil-piercing, which focuses on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation, include whether there is insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, a failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of the corporation as merely a facade for individual dealings.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In determining whether to reverse-pierce the corporate veil, Minnesota courts consider (1) the degree of identity between the individual and his or her corporation and the extent to which the corporation is an alter ego, and (2) whether others, such as a creditor or other shareholders, would be harmed by a pierce.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, when using the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil, courts look to the reality and not form, with how the corporation operated and the individual defendant's relationship to that operation.

Title: In re Wells Fargo Bank, N.A.

Headnote: There are six theories, arising out of common principles of contract and agency law, that may bind nonsignatories to arbitration agreements: (1) incorporation by reference; (2) assumption; (3) agency; (4) alter ego; (5) equitable estoppel; and (6) third-party beneficiary.

Title: Hodak v. Madison Capital Management, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Kentucky courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate entity; corporate veil should not be pierced unless there is (1) such a unity of ownership and interest that the separate personalities of the corporation and its owner cease to exist, and (2) the facts are such that an adherence to the normal attributes of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re KJK Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a corporate entity will be disregarded, and its veil of limited liability pierced, when two requirements are met: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice.

Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the standard test for piercing the corporate veil is two-pronged: (1) plaintiff must demonstrate both that there is such unity of interest and ownership between the individual or entity and the corporation that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or entity no longer exist, and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Title: Emprise Bank v. Rumisek
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Each case involving alter ego and disregard of the corporate entity must rest upon its special facts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Indemnification. Guarantors were entitled, as members of LLC at time they made personal guaranties, to indemnification of the LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Auginaush v. Medure
Court: White Earth Band of Chippewa Tribal Court, Civil Division.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil if an entity ignores corporate formalities and acts as the alter ego or instrumentality of a shareholder and the liability limitations of the corporate form results in injustice or is fundamentally unfair.
Document Preview: NATIVE AMERICANS - Gaming. Tribal court had jurisdiction over tribe's claims against non-member gaming corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Boudreau v. Gentile
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil and hold an individual officer or shareholder liable for his corporation's conduct when (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual do not exist and (2) where the circumstances are such that an adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence promotes injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Companies constituted single enterprise were alter egos of shell company liable for unpaid contributions to union pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: GMAC, LLC v. Hillquist
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must satisfy a two prong test under Illinois law; first, the plaintiff must prove that there is a unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or other corporation no longer exist and, second, the plaintiff must show that circumstances exist such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Sole proprietor was not liable for successor corporation's debts under theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego," as basis for disregarding the corporate fiction, applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego, as basis for disregarding corporate fiction, is shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, including the degree to which corporate formalities have been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, the amount of financial interest, ownership and control the individual maintains over the corporation, and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Labbe v. Carusone
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Evidence did not establish fraudulent transfer after judgment against landlord.

Title: Daniels v. CDB Bell, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Kentucky jurisprudence recognizes three basic theories to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, and these the theories are (1) the instrumentality theory; (2) the alter ego theory; and (3) the equity formulation.

Title: McWilliams Ballard, Inc. v. Broadway Management Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, the corporate entity generally will be respected, but a party may be permitted to pierce the corporate veil upon proof that there is (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A developer stated a claim under District of Columbia law to pierce corporate veil of marketer of units in new development.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Coleman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: In the corporate context, "sham" and "alter ego" are not synonymous: a sham corporation is one established for no valid purpose, such as a corporation formed solely to escape taxation, and does not engage in any business activity, whereas a corporation that is the alter ego of its shareholders and regarded by its owners as a simple "dummy" remains a separate taxable entity, even though its corporate veil might be pierced to allow the corporate creditors to reach the assets of the individual shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Taxes. Double taxation did not warrant disallowance of the IRS' proof of claim for taxes arising from debtor's dividend income.

Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Two conditions generally are required for application of the alter ego doctrine in California to two related corporations: (1) such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate corporate personalities are merged, so that one corporation is a mere adjunct of another or the two companies form a single enterprise; and (2) an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of one corporation alone.

Title: In re Two Springs Membership Club
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Elements required under Nevada law for court to find that individual is alter ego of corporation, each of which must be established by preponderance of evidence, are as follows: (1) that corporation is influenced and governed by alleged alter ego; (2) that there is such unity of interest and ownership between them that one is inseparable from other; and (3) that facts must be such that adherence to corporate fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Chicago Truck Center, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to warrant piercing the corporate veil under Illinois law, plaintiff must make a substantial showing that corporation is really a dummy or sham for a dominating personality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Barnhill's Buffet, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: To prove an "alter ego" theory under Mississippi law, the general rule is that the corporate entity will not be disregarded in contract claims unless the complaining party can demonstrate: (1) some frustration of expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance, (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals, and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Any equitable lien against debtor's leasehold interests terminated upon debtor's bankruptcy filing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Muhs v. River Rats, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Brunswick Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, to establish liability under the alter ego doctrine, a plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) that the stockholders' disregard of the corporate entity made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; (2) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist; and (3) to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Personal Injury. Seller of boat had an ownership interest at the time of the accident sufficient to hold him liable for negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must demonstrate: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership between individual and corporation that separate personalities of corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that circumstances are such that continued adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Like Illinois, South Dakota applies two-pronged test when deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, by considering both whether there is lack of separate corporate identity and whether failing to pierce corporate veil would sanction a fraud or have inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Geiler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, there are three elements to pierce the corporate veil: plaintiff must first show that the corporation is the alter ego of defendant, that is, that defendant completely dominated the corporation in areas such as finance, policy, and business practice; second, plaintiff must show a breach of duty, by showing that defendant used control of the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's rights; and third, plaintiff must prove that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Debtor lacked authority to bind contractor to change orders.

Title: Trevino v. Merscorp, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in order to state claim for piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory, plaintiffs must show that: (1) corporation and its shareholders operated as single economic entity, and (2) overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mortgagors could not pierce corporate veil to hold banks liable for mortgagee's alleged overcharges.

Title: Truck Ins. Exchange v. Palmer J. Swanson, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Requirements for application of alter ego doctrine, which must be established by a preponderance of the evidence, are: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Restaurant Development Group, Inc.

Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.

Headnote: The single business enterprise doctrine is not synonymous with the doctrine of alter ego; although the alter ego doctrine and the single business enterprise doctrine are both based on principles of equity, an important distinction is that the alter ego doctrine generally involves proof of fraud, whereas no proof of fraud is required under the single business enterprise doctrine.

Title: Red River Wings, Inc. v. Hoot, Inc.

Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the corporate veil may be pierced when the corporation is an alter ego of an individual.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Claims of patent on computer system for managing sales information were invalid as anticipated by prior art.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Basic Management Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, Nevada law requires that: (1) the corporation is influenced and governed by the stockholder asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that corporation and the stockholder are inseparable from each other, and (3) adherence to the corporate fiction of a separate entity would sanction fraud or promote a manifest injustice. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Owners of hazardous waste disposal site could not recover under CERCLA for remediation costs paid for by their insurers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Basic Management Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Federal alter ego test for piercing corporate veil requires consideration of: (1) the amount of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders, (2) the fraudulent intent of the incorporators, and (3) the degree of injustice visited on the litigants by recognition of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Owners of hazardous waste disposal site could not recover under CERCLA for remediation costs paid for by their insurers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Trustees of the Graphic Communications Intern. Union Upper Midwest Local 1M Health and Welfare Plan v. Bjorkedal
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine as developed under corporate law provides that the legal fiction of the separate corporate entity may be rejected in the case of a corporation that (1) is controlled by another to the extent that it has independent existence in form only and (2) is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Rental partnership was not alter ego of printing company, as to make it liable for company's contractual obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Trustees of the Graphic Communications Intern. Union Upper Midwest Local 1M Health and Welfare Plan v. Bjorkedal
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, a two part test is applied in considering whether to pierce the corporate veil to reach the shareholders: first, the court must determine whether the corporation is the alter ego or a mere instrumentality of the shareholder, and second, the court must make a finding of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Rental partnership was not alter ego of printing company, as to make it liable for company's contractual obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the corporate form can be disregarded under the "alter ego" theory when a corporate entity has been so completely dominated that the corporate entity had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence, and has been so dominated in order to commit a fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Pleading. Alleged infringers could not respond to patent assignee's allegations without undue burden and prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Capparelli v. AmeriFirst Home Imp. Finance Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, when a corporation operates as mere instrumentality or alter ego of its sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of declared public policy or statute of North Carolina, corporate entity will be disregarded and corporation and shareholder treated as one and the same person.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Non-diverse defendant corporation was fraudulently joined.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate entity will be disregarded, and corporate veil will be pierced, if veil is obstacle to protection of private rights, or if corporation is mere alter ego or business conduit of dominating personality.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. LLC's veil could not be pierced to hold its members liable for LLC's breach of contract to purchase estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Two elements must be met in order to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. LLC's veil could not be pierced to hold its members liable for LLC's breach of contract to purchase estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brown v. Kinross Gold U.S.A., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Where the alter ego doctrine applies, the two corporations are treated as one for purposes of determining liability; the effect of applying the alter ego doctrine is that the corporation and the individual who dominates it are treated as one, so that any act committed by one is attributed to both, and if either is bound, by contract, judgment, or otherwise, both are equally bound.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Issue of whether corporation and subsidiary were alter egos precluded summary judgment on breach of contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Brown v. Kinross Gold U.S.A., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: The ownership of corporate shares is a strong factor favoring unity of ownership and interest for purposes of alter ego test used to pierce the corporate veil under Nevada law; however, the absence of corporate ownership is not dispositive.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Issue of whether corporation and subsidiary were alter egos precluded summary judgment on breach of contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Gasparini v. Pordomingo
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil three factors must be proven: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President of corporation could not be held personally liable for corporation's alleged unjust enrichment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Gasparini v. Pordomingo
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Even if a corporation is merely an alter ego of its dominant shareholder or shareholders, the corporate veil cannot be pierced so long as the corporation's separate identity was lawfully maintained.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President of corporation could not be held personally liable for corporation's alleged unjust enrichment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: Amore ex rel. Estates of Amore v. Accor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Traditional notions of piercing the corporate veil involve shareholders and officers who may be held personally liable for their corporations' obligations if they have acted as alter egos of their corporations or otherwise met the requirements of piercing the corporate veil under traditional common law principles.
Document Preview: TORTS - Judgment. Dismissal of subsidiary from wrongful death action was final court order for res judicata purposes.

Title: Amore ex rel. Estates of Amore v. Accor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In the District of Columbia a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must prove by affirmative evidence that (1) unity of ownership interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Judgment. Dismissal of subsidiary from wrongful death action was final court order for res judicata purposes.

Headnote: Under Georgia alter ego doctrine, corporate entity may be disregarded for liability purposes when it is shown that corporate form has been abused.

Title: Dismuke v. Rand Cook Auto Sales, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Generally, corporate officers and directors are not individually liable for the debts and obligations of the company; however, the officers and directors may be held liable for the debts of the corporation when the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of a governing or a dominating personality.

Headnote: Missouri alter ego standard applies to a creditor's bill in equity.

Title: Ivanov v. Sunset Pools Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to determine whether a corporation and shareholder have abused the corporate form, the inquiry ultimately turns on whether the corporation is, in reality, an alter ego or business conduit of the person in control.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law must demonstrate that (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership between the individual and the corporation that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) the circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Asperger v. Shop Vac Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in rare instances courts will disregard the corporate form to impose liability on shareholders and affiliated corporations if there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or other corporation no longer exist and circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Removal. Defendant manufacturer failed to show fraudulent joinder of non-diverse retailer warranting removal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1039 Alter ego in general >
Title: T & R Trucking, Inc. v. Maynard
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in order to hold the shareholders actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable for breach to party who entered into the contract with the corporation, there is normally a two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual shareholders no longer exist (a disregard of formalities requirement) and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone (a fairness requirement).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Revocation of corporate license during contract term did not provide basis to hold president individually liable for breach.
